div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE favourable reception which the following Comedy has met with from a candid and generous Public, calls for my warmeſt acknowledgements; and tho' it may be of little conſequence to them to know the ſource of ſo ſlight an amuſement, I think myſelf bound by truth and gratitude to own, that the firſt idea of this Piece was hinted to me by my ever-reſpected and lamented friend Mr. GARRICK, who mentioned GOLDONI's Bourru Bienfaiſant, as a ſketch that, if adapted to our times and manners, might be rendered pleaſing to an Engliſh Audience. Thoſe who have read the French Piece muſt judge how far I have profited by GOLDONI's work; but of this I am certain, that had Mr. GARRICK lived to afford me that friendly aſſiſtance which he has done on former occaſions, my Comedy would have been more worthy of the reception with which it has been honoured. I will, however, hope that, with all its imperfections on its head, the ſame indulgence which attended its repreſentation, will follow it into the cloſet; and that the Reader will allow me the only merit I preſume to claim, that of meaning well.

I gladly take this opportunity of returning my thanks to my much-eſteemed friend, Mr. SHERIDAN, ſenior, for his kind attention to the getting up my Play, my ill health not permitting me to attend one Rehearſal. But Mr. SHERIDAN's friendſhip, wherever profeſſed, is not of modern growth.

I have more than common acknowledgements to make to all the Performers in my Comedy; particularly to Mrs. ABINGTON and Miſs POPE, who both chearfully undertook Parts out of their uſual line of acting, and in which they have both excelled. I ſhould be utterly unable to expreſs my ſentiments of Mr. KING, in the character of SIR WILLIAM WOODLEY, if I were not at liberty ſeriouſly to adopt the very words which he humorouſly, but juſtly, ſpeaks of himſelf, under a perſonated character, in The Critic:— But it is impoſſible for language to do juſtice to Mr. KING! Indeed, he more than merited thoſe repeated burſts of applauſe which he drew from a moſt brilliant and judicious Audience.

I flatter myſelf, this little tribute to diſtinguiſhed merit will not be deemed tedious or impertinent by the Public, for whoſe opinion I have the ſincereſt reſpect, and to whom I have the honour to be

closer.signed: A much obliged, And moſt obedient Servant, THE AUTHOR.

lg.l: TO glow with ardour, and attempt with zeal
The reformation of the public weal,
Is the high duty of the COMIC MUSE;
And tho' keen Attic Salt allowed to uſe,
To ſeaſon Precept, and with Art to tickle
The ſores ſhe means to waſh with ſharpeſt pickle,
Yet not the roſy, pulpited Divine,
Nor lank-hair'd Methodiſt with rueful whine,
Is more intent to root out Vice and Folly,
And make ye all lead lives diſcreet and holy.—
Yet why to clear the field were all their toil,
If weeds o'erſpread not the luxuriant ſoil?
Congreve or Weſley, Whitfield or Moliere,
In vain might prompt the laugh, or bribe the tear,
If no man felt, or in himſelf, or neighbour,
Some failing to call forth the zealot's labour;—
If no fair dame deſcried, 'midſt her acquaintance,
Some few who might be mended by repentance.
Looſe as the buxom air, the Youth from College
Comes fraught with all Newmarket's hopeful knowledge;
In haſte to ſpend the Eſtate, not yet his own,
Compleats his ruin ere his beard is grown;
And when to foreign climes he ſpreads the ſail,
'Tis not to enlarge his mind, but 'ſcape a jail.
Then bleſt the Poet, happy the Divine,
When Folly gives the Ton from Faſhion's Shrine!
But whilſt the Prieſt and Satiriſt reprove
Thoſe vices which provoke the wrath of JOVE,
Our Author, like the patient Angler ſitting
To catch ſmall fry, for humbler palates ſitting,
Has ſerved a Meal, not ſeaſoned high with crimes.—
Taſte it, and if approved, applaud THE TIMES.
WHILE grave-paced Tragedy, with Oh's! and Starts!
Flies at high game, to move and mend your hearts,
We merrier folks, with ſpirits blithe and jolly,
Juſt perch upon ſome little ſprig of folly:
For, in this Age, ſo pious, chaſte, and grave,
To rail at Vice, muſt ſurely be to rave!
Yet thanks to here and there a modiſh fool,
The COMIC MUSE may glean ſome ridicule.
Jews will be Jews, if dupes can yet be found,
And if one frail one's left on Engliſh ground,
She'll find a Phaeton and pair of ponies
To elope—for all men are not Maccaronies:—
Thoſe precious Dears, at leaſt, would make her wait—
'Twould be ſo vulgar, not to be too late.
Our ſex—but ſhall I charge the weaker kind?
Or can thoſe fail to ſtray, whoſe guides are blind!
Let men reform themſelves, they're our examples—
And goods prove ſeldom better than their ſamples.
In former times the gallant Britiſh Youth
Were formed for Chivalry, and Love, and Truth—
In ſuch an Age, in ſuch a virtuous Nation,
Love was in woman almoſt inſpiration.—
But now, alas! I ſpeak without a jeſt,
Women are not inſpired—they're but poſſeſt.
Men are our pilots! They ſhould mark the ſhelves;
For when they blame us, they reproach themſelves.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE, A Dreſſing-room, Books, Muſic, Clothes ſcattered about.
Mr. WOODLEY dreſſing, FORWARD at a diſtance.
div.p: SURE, never man was ſo ſuddenly involved as I have been!—and yet I cannot charge either my wife or myſelf with any particular extravagance. We do but live like other people of our rank; and yet, in leſs than four years that we have been married, an eſtate of four thouſand pounds a-year has dwindled into nothing!—Heigh-ho!— (obſerving Forward liſtening, he hums a tune) —I can neither get this Air into my head, or out of it.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: I am often plagued ſo, myſelf, Sir, after the firſt night of a new Opera, tho' I have a tolerable ear, and catch a tune pretty readily.
sp.stage: Enter a Footman, and delivers a Letter to Mr. Woodley. He reads it, and appears agitated.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: What a propoſal!—I would die firſt. Get me pen, ink, and paper

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: I'll fetch them inſtantly from the Library, Sir.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: You need not. I'll write there.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p:
He ſeems deviliſhly flurried by that ſame letter. I wiſh I could come fairly at its contents. 'Tis no billet-doux, I am certain; for I have never found him tripping that way, ſince I have been in the family. It muſt be ſome matter of buſineſs, and if it is, it may concern me as well as my maſter. I have had my doubts that our affairs were going wrong, for ſome months paſt. Our hall has been crowded with ſturdy Tradeſmen, and we have had ſneaking Jews cloſeted in the Library.—Egad, I'll venture; for where intereſt is concerned, even my honour muſt give way— (takes up the letter). He may ſurpriſe me, tho'.—I wiſh his ſhoes creaked (looks out and liſtens).—No—all's ſafe yet; and now for the indulgence of a reaſonable curioſity.— (reads.)
I find it impoſſible to trifle any longer with your creditors; the executions will therefore immediately be laid on, unleſs you can prevail on Lady Mary to releaſe her jointure; for there is not even a Jew in Duke's-Place that will advance a guinea more on your eſtate, whilſt that incumbrance remains.
I am your humble ſervant, JOHN FLEECE'EM.
P. S. I have ſcarce caſh enough in my hands to diſcharge the incloſed ſmall bill of coſts.
Here's a bill, as long as his Taylor's!

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p:
Puppy! What are you meddling with
thoſe papers for? Give this letter to James, and order him to carry it inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: Muſt I not put the things to rights, firſt, Sir?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Do as I order you, and leave the room.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: Ay, and the place, too, as ſoon as your Honour can provide yourſelf. (aſide.) I ſhould not chuſe to depend upon a poſt obit for my wages.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: How ſhall I be able to reveal my ſituation to Lady Mary! My heart bleeds for what ſhe muſt ſuffer!

sp.speaker: Footman.
sp.p: Colonel Mountfort, Sir.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Deſire him to walk in.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Good-morrow, Woodley! What, not dreſſed yet! I expected to find you booted, and ready to ſet out for Newmarket. You'll be late on the turf. Your horſes run, I ſuppoſe? What matches have you made?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: None, Colonel. I ſhall not be there, this Meeting.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You amaze me.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Would I had never been there! I am ſick of the diverſion, and ſhall never make another bett on the turf while I live.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why don't you diſpoſe of your ſtud, then? It muſt be an enormous, and now an uſeleſs expence.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Horſes are the leaſt part of the extravagances incident to racing.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That is ſelon, Woodley; for I have known ſeveral fortunes made on the turf.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: True—but by thoſe only who had none to loſe. They are ſureſt to win, who carry leaſt weight.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Take my advice, then, and ſell your horſes.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Why, faith, I wiſh they were diſpoſed of. But yet, I don't know, I ſhould be aſhamed, I think, to advertiſe them, as it might look ſome-how as if one could not afford to keep them. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Ridiculous ſuppoſition!

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Ridiculous, indeed! That you know, Mountfort, is far from the caſe, but I really am tired of the ſport; and the Meeting, too, is at a time of the year when there are ſo many more agreeable amuſements to be met with in London, ſo that I ſhould be glad to get rid of them, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Let me diſpoſe of them for you, then. I'll be your Auctioneer, and try if I can't emblazon their pedigree with a little of that true humour which Charles Surface beſtows on his anceſtors, when he ſets up their pictures to ſale. Bucephalus, the famous Bucephalus, Gentlemen, deſcended in a right line from the renowned quadrupede of that name, which had the honour of carrying a greater brute than himſelf—the immortal Alexander—

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Bravo! Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Or ſhall we deduce his lineage from—

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: You had better conſult Tatterſall, for their pedigree, as he is your only herald in thoſe points. Heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Heigh-ho! This is but poor encouragement for me to enter on my new profeſſion. Surely there is ſomething malignant in the air, at preſent; for every man I have converſed with, this morning, ſeems rather to be depreſſed with the gloom of November, than enlivened by the ſunſhine of April. I have juſt now left Jack Knightly and Will Careleſs calculating, not their nativities, but their deaths.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I ſaw them both at Boodle's, yeſterday, in good health.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Not the more likely to live, for that, I aſſure you. However, it was not their natural exiſtence,
but their neceſſary ſubſiſtence, that employed their mathematics.

sp.speaker: Mr. Woodley.
sp.p: You aſtoniſh me!—Why, it is but lately they came into poſſeſſion of great eſtates.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: True:—but then they have travelled the modern ſhort and eaſy road to ruin, of granting annuities for this twelvemonth paſt, and are now ſo nearly arrived at the laſt ſtage of their journey, that I think Jack ſaid he had but two months to run; and Will flattered himſelf, that as the ſummer was approaching, he might be able to hold out four. I adviſed their compounding the terms, and running together for three months each.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Poor fellows! I am ſorry for them. (aſide.) Would I could promiſe myſelf even ſo long a reprieve.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: What! moping again, Woodley? You'll infect me, if I ſtay.—Where are the Ladies?—In truth, my viſit was to them, for I ſcarce hoped to find you here. Are Lady Mary and your ſiſter viſible? or ſhall I paſs on to your Uncle's apartment, and pay my reſpects to him? I think there is a door of communication to his houſe from this room. Shall I go this way?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: That may be a ſervice of danger, Colonel; for I fear Sir William is not at preſent much delighted either with his vicinity, or affinity, to any of this family, except my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am glad to hear you can except my ſweet Louiſa; for, notwithſtanding the bruſqueneſs of his manners, I have ſuch an opinion of the old Knight's good ſenſe and good nature, that I cannot readily acquit thoſe he is offended with, as wholly free from blame.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p:
I ſubſcribe to your cenſure, as far as it relates to myſelf; but the aſperity of his behaviour to Lady Mary, renders me extremely unhappy; and not even my paſt obligations, or future proſpects,
ſhall ever make me acquieſce in his treating my wife with diſreſpect.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Allow me to ſay, Woodley, that perſons ſo nearly connected, ought to diſpenſe with ceremony, in favour of ſincerity.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: That's a dangerous tenet, Colonel, and may be extended 'till downright rudeneſs may be conſidered but as the privilege of family-chat.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I think you have no cauſe for ſuch an apprehenſion, in this caſe, as Sir William is quite as ſingular for goodneſs of heart, as for a deficiency in that outward varniſh which too often ſupplies the place of it. But to compound the argument, let us admit there may be faults on both ſides.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: My dear Woodley, don't I look like a hag, to-day? Do you know that I have not ſlept an hour, the whole night!

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for it, my dear:—I hope it was not any illneſs that prevented your reſt.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: No—I was not the leaſt ill; but the uncommon brilliancy of Lady Muſhroom's ear-rings, that I ſaw at the Opera, in the evening, twinkled all night before my eyes, and would not ſuffer me to cloſe them.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Vanity has her vigils, I perceive, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: That's but fair, Colonel, as her feſtivals ſeem to beſtow ſuch ſupreme delight on her votaries of both ſexes.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I think, now, that a thouſand pounds added to my own, would make them out-blaze Lady Muſhroom's; and I am ſure my dear Woodley won't refuſe me ſuch a trifle.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I can refuſe you nothing—but we'll talk of it ſome other time.
sp.stage: Enter a Servant and delivers a Letter to Mr. Woodley, which he juſt runs his eye over, and puts up.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: What makes you look ſo grave, my Love? I ſhould almoſt ſuppoſe that letter was from your Uncle, if he did not live in the ſame houſe, and had not a peculiar delight in ſeeing the effect of his own ill temper.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: The reprehenſions of ſincere friends proceed oftener from kindneſs, than ill-nature.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Will you ſend for Setwell to-morrow, my Dear, if you are not at leiſure to-day? I muſt have this bar taken out, the middle ſtone larger, and the drop at leaſt twice this ſize: and pray hurry him, for I muſt poſitively wear them at Court, next Sunday.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: It muſt be ſo.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You don't attend to me, Mr. Woodley?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: O, yes, my Dear, I hear every word you ſay. Give me the ear-rings, I'll carry them myſelf to the Jeweller.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Here they are;—but don't be too extravagant:—I would not have more than a thouſand pounds added, on any account.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I give you credit for that laſt caution, Lady Mary; as 'tis uncommon to hear a wife reſtraining her huſband's generoſity to herſelf, in this day.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: His indulgence, Colonel, has ever exceeded my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: But never equalled my own. (aſide.) My heart is breaking for her.
sp.stage: Enter a Servant, who gives a printed Paper to Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: With Mrs. Bromley's compliments, Madam, and requeſts you'll do her the honour to call on her.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: O! 'tis the Catalogue ſhe promiſed to mark for me. My compliments, and I ſhall be at her door in a few minutes.—Louiſa, are you diſpoſed for Chriſt • e's Rooms, this morning? There are abundance of fine things, and, of courſe, fine people, to be there. I delight in an Auction, one meets with ſo many things there, one never thought one wanted before.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Though it is not my paſſion, I'll attend your Ladyſhip with pleaſure.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: See, Woodley, what an unconſcionable creature Bromley is! She has marked a whole ſide of the Catalogue.—A luſtre that holds a hundred lights! I think I ſhould like that, now, for our grand ſaloon, in the country. I own, I ſhould delight vaſtly to aſtoniſh our neighbours in Dorſetſhire—if ever we go there. Have you any objection, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: But one, my Dear—I am to ſettle with my Banker, to day.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: No matter—Mrs. Bromley ſhall be my Banker. Her purſe is always at the ſervice of her friends.—O, here's the ſweeteſt ſett of fillagree dreſſing-plate!—I muſt have that, Woodley, inſtead of the one I have had theſe two years.—'Tis abſolutely Gothic.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I cannot wound her by reſtraint.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Don't you think Mrs. Bromley a delightful creature, Colonel?—Two of the largeſt Seve vaſes that have ever been imported. I poſitively muſt have them. How good it was in the dear Bromley to note theſe articles!—Why don't you tell me how you like my friend?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I have not the honour, Madam, of knowing her ſufficiently to judge of her character, and therefore can only ſpeak of it as doubtful.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Doubtful, Colonel!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: In ſome caſes, Lady Mary, to doubt, is rather to compliment, than to cenſure.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And, in other caſes, to doubt, is to be certain.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You don't affect to be doubtful, I hope, Miſs Woodley?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: By no means, I aſſure you. Mrs. Bromley's character is quite clear to me.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: If you talk in this ſtile, Louiſa, I ſhall certainly conclude that you are jealous of the dear Bromley.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I know not on what account I ſhould be ſo, except in your good graces; for I hope you don't think me vain enough to attempt rivalling her with her preſent Ceciſbeo, Sir Harry Granger.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That ridiculous compound of affectation and epicuriſm! who ruminates upon every meal, and tries to preſerve the reliſh of his ſauces, by a repetition of their ingredients in every new company that admits him.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You are monſtrouſly cenſorious, Colonel; but I will allow that he is a little out of faſhion, at preſent; and for that reaſon, I have forbidden his ever coming into this houſe. The Bromleys dine here to-day, my Dear (to Mr. Woodley.)—But we loſe time. The Auction may begin, and ſome of the dear things I have ſet my heart upon be gone before we get there.—I ſhall never forget that old frightful Mandarin, Lord Gobble, for whipping up the Seve China Dejeuner from me, at the laſt ſale.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Will your Ladyſhip permit me to have the honour of attending you?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: There's a vacant ſeat in the coach, and you ſhall be welcome, if you won't be ſpiteful. Good morrow, Woodley! Come, Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p:
So—I am once more left at leiſure for my own reflection. Solitude is ſaid to be a relief to the unhappy; but thought only ſerves to double my diſtreſs. Surely my poverty begins to be apparent,
or Knightly would not write ſo preſſingly.—His note ſurpriſes me. (Reads)
Dear Woodley, I deſire you will, on receipt of this, let me have the three hundred pieces you loſt to me at our laſt Meeting, as I am juſt ſetting off for Newmarket, and muſt have ſome weight of metal to balance the ſcales on the turf. I ſhall wait at home for you exactly one hour, by the beſt going watch in Europe, and muſt have the caſh by that time, pos.
Yours ever, T. KNIGHTLY.

The peremptory ſtile of this billet alarms me! Knightly uſed to be a careleſs, liberal fellow; but Mountfort told me juſt now, that he is on the verge of ruin. His ſtate, however, is to be envied, in compariſon of mine. He falls alone. No wife, no family, at once to ſhare and aggravate his wretchedneſs. I'll go this moment and acquit me of his demand, by parting with theſe toys— (takes up the ear-rings). How much my Mary's beauty added to their luſtre! Let me fly from the thought.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: Juſt on the wing, my dear friend! How lucky thus to catch you flying, as it were!

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: The good fortune is rather mine, Mr. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: No, no; you compliment.—But where are the dear, the divine Ladies?—Mayn't I hope to be cheared with one glance from their bright eyes?—What a beautiful creature is Lady Mary!—Do you know ſhe wants but little, very little, my dear friend, to be the top of the tree, the very paragon of fine taſte and bon ton; and I think ſhe will very ſoon acquire that little. My Dame has an excellent hand at touching up the laſt poliſh.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I allow Mrs. Bromley to be perfectly elegant.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: No, no; there you are wrong.—She is pretty, lively, and ſo forth, but ſomewhat ſubſy, you know.—But Lady Mary, Lady Mary is the thing!—But what's here? (taking up the ear-rings)—A new purchaſe, I preſume? They are fine, very fine, indeed! What now may the value be?—Some thouſands, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: They did coſt a pretty large ſum, when they were bought.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: Not new, then, I perceive—but fine, very fine, indeed!

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Lady Mary don't quite like the faſhion—the ſetting, I mean;—and therefore I ſhould not be ſorry to part with them—and buy others.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: O, that alters the caſe conſiderably! Let us ſee—let's ſee. Why now, upon examining them cloſely, they appear but middling, very middling, indeed. I don't wonder Lady Mary ſhould not like them—no luſtre—very old faſhion'd—they'll ſell for little or nothing, believe me.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: They coſt me fifteen hundred pounds, about four years ago.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: Fifteen hundred pounds!—You amaze me!—You muſt have been ſadly impoſed upon! very ſadly, indeed, my dear friend! What monſtrous cheats theſe tradesfolks are!—Why, theſe jewels, now, will not bring above three hundred.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: That's more than the common diſproportion between buying and ſelling, I ſhould think, Mr. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p:
I mean in the Trade, Mr. Woodley. Among the Trade, diamonds are a drug, a mere drug, indeed: and money is a rare jewel in all trades now, I'll aſſure you. A Gentleman, or a friend, perhaps, might give more. Come, for the frolic's ſake, I'll turn jeweller myſelf, and offer you a cool five
hundred for them. What ſay you? Is it a bargain, Woodley?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I cannot bear the thought of carrying them abroad to ſell!—Well, if you really think they are worth no more—

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: Nay, I have over-rated them; but I never compute by pounds, ſhillings, and pence, when dealing with a friend. Diamonds are, as I told you before, a mere drug; and caſh, caſh, my dear boy, your only valuable commodity. Here, here it is (looking in his pocket-book).—I have not quite ſo much about me, I find.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: That's unlucky (looking at his watch); for I want three hundred of it, this very inſtant.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: Does the wind ſit in that point?—I'll ſee—I'll ſee. O! here is juſt the three hundred, cut and dry, my boy. You ſhall have the other two this evening at Boodle's. We'll cut a card, or throw a caſt for it, or how you will.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I ſhan't go to Boodle's to-night—nor do I think I ſhall ever play again.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: The knowing-ones are taken in. I would not have given ſo much for the jewels, if I had thought ſo.—What, not play? That's good, very good, indeed! You have a ſort of lover's quarrel to the dice, I perceive. But though they have, I confeſs, uſed you a little ſcurvily, they'll make you amends ſome other time. One lucky hit, you know, may repay all your loſſes.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: They have ſo often, and ſo fatally deceived me—

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: That you'll truſt them again, for all that.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I think not. But we ſhall meet at dinner?

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p:
Yes, yes; I obey the dear, ſweet Lady Mary's invitation. I ſhall bring the money with me. Beſides, I recollect, that you and I have a little
matter of buſineſs to ſettle; but it ſhan't break in upon our pleaſures, tho'. You ſhall have no trouble but juſt to ſet your name. A memorandum is all I want, my boy.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I have a particular reaſon for deſiring that you will not mention the tranſaction of the jewels to my wife, or even to yours.

sp.speaker: Bromley.
sp.p: Secret—ſecret as the grave, my dear friend—truſty as ſteel, my boy. You may always depend upon honeſt Bob Bromley. We ſhall be with you at five, tho' that's rather early (going).—Nay, no ceremony.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I am going out this moment.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: I have liſtened and pryed to good purpoſe, I think, and am thoroughly confirmed in my reſolution of ſhifting my quarters, to-morrow morning. Up tents, and away, then! But I cannot help being a little concerned at leaving my maſter and Lady; becauſe I am ſure I ſhall never get ſo good a place again. All maſters—no ſervants—every one did as he liked. It grieves me to think what a hand the reſt of the ſervants have made of them. There's the lazy Houſekeeper, the drunken Butler, the cribbing Coachman!—But what ſignifies moralizing! Let me look about me a little, and ſee if there be any ſmall matters lying looſe, that are of no farther uſe to my maſter, and may be of ſome to me.— (Takes up a pair of lace ruffles) Theſe have been worn, but never waſhed, and he may miſs them. No, that's not probable, as he has at leaſt twenty pair more than he knows any thing of— (puts them in his pocket). This ſnuff-box, too, is but a bauble, of more curioſity than value: I ſhall accept of it as a keep-ſake— (pockets it).
sp.stage: Enter Sir William, from the middle door.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: By the quietneſs in the neſt, the birds are flown; and I am glad of it. My apartment ſmokes a little, to-day. I'll have the tables brought here, and try if the game be recoverable: tho', to be ſure, I have but little hopes; for ſure there never was any man ſo unlucky.—Waters!

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: What! is old Square-Toes ruined, too? Egad, I ſhould be glad of that.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: —Why, hey, what are you doing here?—Waters! I ſay—

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: Only removing a few uſeleſs things of my maſter's, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Then you will certainly remove yourſelf; for I know nothing half ſo uſeleſs, as a pert, coxcomical, lazy Valet-de-Chambre.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: As your Honour chuſes to be alone, I ſhall retire directly.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Retire! There's a phraſe now for a footman! But theſe puppies all mimic their maſters, even in their language, and what's worſe, in their vices. I'll anſwer for it that fellow now, is as idle, as diſſipated, and extravagant, as my nephew himſelf. But why do I think of a man whoſe miſconduct has ſo totally alienated my affections? Yet he was a ſweet boy at Eton, and a fine youth at College. His indiſcreet marriage has ruined him—a fine Lady—a Lady of Quality, forſooth, and without a fortune to ſupport her vanity. But, no matter now—I renounce them both.—Waters!—I wiſh Louiſa was removed from this ſcene of folly and extravagance, and ſafely ſettled in the country. There is no other place for a woman to be ſecure in.
I wiſh you would advance, Mr. Slow-boots. I have called you at leaſt a dozen times.

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p: I came the very moment—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, well, well—apologies take up time.—Bring the back-gammon tables here, then go to Counſellor Belford, and deſire him to come to me, directly.— (Waters going through the middle door)—Why don't you go the ſhorteſt way?

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p: Your Honour bid me bring the tables, firſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Of what uſe are they, when Belford is not here to play?— (Waters going)—No, come back, and fetch the tables, and I'll place the men juſt to ſhew you how I was gammoned, and I think you'll allow there never was ſuch luck.

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p: I am utterly ignorant of every point of the game, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Stupidity in the abſtract! How often have you been in the room, while Belford and I have been playing! Had we been ſaying or doing any thing we ought not, you would have picked it up faſt enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No words—I hate prate—fly to Mr. Belford's— [Exit Waters]—I'll go and ſhew Jones how it was; for tho' ſhe is my Houſekeeper, now, ſhe is a Parſon's daughter, and muſt underſtand backgammon. I am ſure ſhe will be aſtoniſhed at Belford's move.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter, at oppoſite doors, Mr. WOODLEY, and Mr. BELFORD.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: HOW truly do I rejoice to ſee my good friend Mr. Belford! But may I flatter myſelf that the honour of this viſit was intended for me?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I am ſorry, my dear Sir, that there ſhould be a neceſſity for diſcriminating the perſon to whom my reſpects are paid, in a family I ſo equally regard, and which was once ſo happily united.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: If indeed you regard this family, or ever had any friendſhip for me—But I cannot ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I am already apprized of your difficulties, and would ſpare you the pain of even hinting at them, were it in my power to redreſs them.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Then be aſſured it is; for amidſt all my diſtreſſes, nothing afflicts me half ſo much as Sir William's implacable reſentment againſt Lady Mary and me. If he were but reconciled—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: That is, in plain Engliſh, my young friend, if he could be reconciled to your expenſive mode of living, he ought in honour to aſſiſt in ſupporting it. But that, I doubt, will never be brought to paſs, though Sir William is both rich and generous—

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: To all the world, but me.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p:
In this caſe, then, you ſhould ſuſpect your own conduct, rather than his character.—But remonſtrances are uſeleſs, now; and I promiſe to uſe my utmoſt intereſt to bring about a reconciliation.
But I much fear that we ſhall not be able to get Lady Mary included in the family-compact; for I know no man more reſolute in what he conceives to be right, than Sir William.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: My honour, as well as my love, obliges me to vindicate her; and I here pledge them both, that ſhe is free from blame.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I am glad to find you ſtill a lover, Mr. Woodley; but I who am but a friend, in this queſtion, can't help thinking, that if Lady Mary had ſpent more of her time in Dorſetſhire, and leſs at Spa, Paris, and other places of diſſipation and extravagance, ſhe would have been more entitled to Sir William's eſteem, and you would have had leſs need of his aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: The fault was mine alone.—Vain of poſſeſſing ſuch a treaſure—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You childiſhly expoſed it to the gaze of fops and foreigners.—And let me tell you, Mr. Woodley, you are a lucky man, in theſe licentious times, to have preſerved ſuch a gem pure and entire, even at the expence of your other poſſeſſions. But, prithee, why don't you now retreat into the country?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: My wife is quite ignorant of my preſent circumſtances—I have not reſolution to acquaint her with them—and to propoſe quitting London, in this gay ſeaſon, without aſſigning ſome cauſe—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Would, in your ſituation, be extremely prudent.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I cannot bear the thought of giving her uneaſineſs—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: And ſo cruelly prefer the evil to the cure.

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p:
I humbly beg your Honour's pardon for my intruſion, but I have been at your Chambers,
and at the Temple Coffee-houſe, to look for you. My maſter is quite impatient to ſee you, Sir, and one of Mr. Woodley's ſervants told me you were here.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: This ſeems to fall out luckily. I will not detain you a moment. Dear Belford, remember what a cauſe you have in hand.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Do not diſtruſt my attention to my client, tho' I cannot warrant ſucceſs to the ſuit.

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p: I cannot tell your Honour how proud I am to meet you. My good, dear maſter has been as angry with me for not finding you at home, as if I had committed the greateſt of faults; and I would die rather than vex him.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I know my friend's haſty temper, perfectly well; but I alſo know that his good-nature is an over-match for it.

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p: O, Sir! you don't know how good and generous he is.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You are miſtaken, Waters; I am no ſtranger to Sir William's benevolence.

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, with ſubmiſſion you are;—for he takes as much pains to conceal his goodneſs, as others do to reveal theirs. He would never forgive me if he knew I mentioned it; but my heart is ſo glad, I can't help telling your Honour that he apprenticed my eldeſt boy, laſt week, and pays for the ſchooling of the two youngeſt.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Theſe are noble bounties, I confeſs, Waters; but I think your feelings on the occaſion do as much honour to human nature, as the Knight's generoſity;—for a liberal hand is more frequently to be met with, than a grateful heart.—But where is Sir William?

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p:
I left him going to take a turn in the garden, and I don't in the leaſt doubt but he will come in as cool as a cucumber, tho' when he went
down ſtairs he was as angry with me, as if he had never done me any good.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Shew me the way, and I'll go to him directly.
sp.stage: SCENE changes to a Dreſſing-Room, an elegant Toilet.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: They are pretty, I confeſs; but even I think them rather dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: What an idea for my dear Lady Mary! Do you know, now, that the equipage of Mrs. Stockwell's toilet, the Broker's wife, coſt thirteen hundred pounds?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I remember her at Paris—an overdreſſed Thing!—I thought ſhe had been a Jeweller's wife, and looked upon her as a ſtalking ſhew-glaſs, to expoſe her huſband's goods for ſale. But the poor man, I ſuppoſe, was ruined by her extravagance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he was done-up, very ſoon after. But the woman had wit in her madneſs, however; for ſhe ſecreted her paraphernalia, and her chariot has rolled on her perſonal fortune, ever ſince. Women are much wiſer, now-a-days, than they uſed to be.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Williams.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip's maſquerade dreſs is juſt come home, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Let me ſee! let me ſee!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: How beautiful! My dear creature, You'll look a Goddeſs, and you'll move a Queen!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Ah, Bromley! I have juſt recollected that I can't go as a Sultana. I have ſent my ear-rings to be altered, and the reſt of my jewels will make no figure without them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Hire, hire, my Dear.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: What a baby, Mrs. Williams! but 'tis a ſweet baby, we muſt allow. Why, for fifty, or a hundred guineas, at moſt, you may hire as many diamonds as would out-blaze the throne of Dehli.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: A hundred guineas! What a ſum for one night's vanity! No—I'll go as a Shepherdeſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: That wou'd be a diſguiſe, indeed, in theſe days of martial ardour, when our whole Sex have exchanged their old faſhion'd ſimplicity of dreſs and manners, for the military air, the ſmart cockade, and lively regimental.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: But one may be allowed to look innocent in maſquerade, I hope?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Ha, my little fly one! have I found you out?—Nothing but a Corydon cou'd have inſpired ſuch an idea.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: All dreſſes, I fancy, are alike to Mr. Woodley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Mr. Woodley! Ridiculous! Why, ſurely, my dear, you don't think of expoſing yourſelf to be the jeſt of the whole Town, by going en groupe with your huſband to a Maſquerade!—Would not the dear, good natured Sir Harry Granger, or even the wiſe Colonel Mountfort, make a better Corydon for our ſweet Shepherdeſs, think you?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: How idly you talk!—Mountfort is Louiſa's Ceciſbeo, and Sir Harry, I fancy, would be proud to enliſt under your banner, in the ſame capacity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: This is wilful blindneſs, Lady Mary, for you can't avoid ſeeing that Sir Harry is your ſlave. I pity him with all my heart, and w • ſh you would do ſo too. Poor ſoul, how he doats upon you!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You'll make me angry, Mrs. Bromley.—But, prithee, why muſt I be treated like a picture for a drawing room, not to be hung up without its companion? I want no Corydon, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: No, to be ſure—quite lonely and diſcreet. Come, come, my dear Lady Mary, you were not deſigned for a ſimple Shepherdeſs:—the Sultana is your natural character—born to command, and be adored. But you muſt and ſhall be fine; for let the men ſay what they will of native charms, our diamonds add conſiderably to the luſtre of our eyes. What ſay you, Mrs. Williams?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Williams.
sp.p: There never was a truer word ſpoken, Ma'am; for though my Lady wants no offſettings, and looks like an angel in any dreſs—

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: A truce with your flattery, Williams!—Take away the dreſs—I ſhall conſider of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Williams.
sp.p: Nobody's flattery will go down, now, but Mrs. Bromley's, it ſeems.

sp.speaker: L. Mary
sp.p: I ſhould like the Sultana, I confeſs; but—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Can't you gueſs? You know I have been ſtripped at play, and have ſquandered a great deal of money, this morning. I am ſorry I bought theſe toys.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Bleſs me! how you talk? you that have the fondeſt, and the moſt indulgent huſband breathing!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: For that very reaſon, my dear Bromley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: You really talk like a wife of the laſt century.—Here's a fuſs, indeed, about a poor hundred guineas! Do you know, now, that I would not have this ſtory told of you, in any polite circle, for treble the ſum.—If it ſhould take wind, you'd be ſneered to death with encomiums on your Ladyſhip's very uncommon prudence.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p:
Why, I ſhould not care to be thought
too prudent, neither; ſo I beg you'll not mention it to any one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: You may rely on my friendſhip.—And now, my Dear, what jewels would you have?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You can't imagine how much diſtreſſed I am, upon this trifling ſubject. I'm reſolved not to aſk Mr Woodley for money, to-day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Borrow, then. You may command thouſands, to my knowledge. Sir Harry is as rich as all Duke's Place, and I am ſure he would be happy to lay all his treaſures at your feet.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Borrow money from Sir Harry Granger!—You cannot mean it!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Sure never mortal was ſo eaſily taken-in, as my dear Lady Mary! You could not think me ſerious, I hope.—Not but I know many wives—

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Who are a reproach to their Sex, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: No preaching, if you love me!—I ſhall get the jewels for you, on my own credit; for I am reſolved that you ſhall not only be the lovelieſt, but the fineſt woman, in all that dear, gay, motley Aſſembly, to-night.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I thank you, my dear Bromley.—I think the dreſs will become me.—But I owe you a monſtrous deal of money, I'm afraid, already.—How much is it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: A trifle, a very trifle, indeed, between ſuch friends! and I ſhall be apt to quarrel with you, if ever you mention it again—let the men ſettle it.—I ſhall bring the jewels with me at five; 'till then, adio mia cara.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Mr. Bromley comes, I hope?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Lord! who knows any thing of a Huſband's engagements, my Dear? But there is no doubt of his attending your ſummons, on any occaſion, for my poor Bromley dies for you. You are quite a monopolizer, Lady Mary!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: What a rattle you are!
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Sir WILLIAM's Apartment
Sir WILLIAM and Mr. BELFORD at Back-gammon.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I tell you, I will hear no more of him.—If he has deſtroyed his fortune, he ſhall not deſtroy my peace.— (throws the dice) Cinque ace.—Come, come, 'tis your throw.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: It is amazing, Sir William, that you can be ſo anxious about this trifling game, and at the ſame time ſo indifferent about your nephew!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I am in earneſt about every thing, Mr. Belford; conſequently, in my reſentment againſt my ſilly nephew, who is a ſlave to his wife, and a victim to his vanity. Will you take the box, I ſay?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Gently, gently, my good Sir William.—You have put yourſelf in a paſſion, already.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir, 'tis you that have put me in a paſſion.—I hate gently, and all the phlegmatic people in the world.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: And yet you and I have been friends, theſe twenty years.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: True, true, my dear Belford!—and, perhaps, I am indebted to your gently, for our continuing ſo.—But don't put my patience to any further trial, at preſent.—Sit down, I entreat you.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But one word more, and I have done.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, I am patient, but don't harp again on the ſame ſtring—No more of Mr. Woodley.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You have a noble fortune, Sir William!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, thanks to Providence! more than I have occaſion for myſelf, and therefore I conſider the overplus but as a bank for my friends.—Do you want money, Belford? Name the ſum, and take it.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Thank you, Sir William, but 'tis not my wants I wiſh you to ſupply, but thoſe of your nephew.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What! at it again? I will not give him a doit—not a doit, Sir. My fortune ſhall not be laviſhed to indulge his vanity, or ſupply his prodigality.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I am perſuaded he has ſo thoroughly reflected upon his paſt folly, that he would make a proper uſe of your future kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Let him alter his conduct, firſt, if he expects I ſhould alter mine. His repentance may merit my bounty; but my liberality ſhall not prevent his reformation.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But if Mr. Woodley ſhould be undone, what will become of your niece?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Let her ſhare his fate, as ſhe has done his folly—ſhe has earned it.—An extravagant woman, that could not be content to live at one of the fineſt Seats in England, but muſt friſk it to Spa and Paris, forſooth, like the reſt of the ſilly Engliſh, to ſquander their money, and be laughed at by Foreigners!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I underſtood Miſs Woodley had remained in England.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, Louiſa! I did not ſpeak of her—ſhe is the beſt girl on earth.—No, no—ſhe ſhan't ſuffer for other people's faults. If he has involved her fortune too, I ſhall take care of her.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Do you intend ſhe ſhall live with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir, no—I'll have no miſtreſs in my houſe, but old Jones. I would not diſplace her for a Ducheſs—it would break the poor woman's heart.—But I ſhall take proper care of Louiſa.— (aſide) I wiſh ſhe was well married, out of the way.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But now give me leave, Sir William—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Neither now, nor then, Mr. Belford. The matter is all ſettled in my mind, and the game gone quite out of my head. I'll ſend for Louiſa, directly, and talk this matter over with her.—Waters! (enter Waters) Step in to Mr. Woodley's, and deſire my niece to come to me immediately.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I am ſorry I have been ſo unſucceſsful in my ſuit, Sir William, and wiſh you a good-day.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You are not angry with me, I hope, Belford?—I am as ſorry for my nephew's indiſcretion as you or any one can be.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: If you are, you will certainly aſſiſt him. (aſide) But I know it muſt be all done in your own way.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Dine with me, and we'll play out our party, after dinner.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: With all my heart, but I ſhall be too many for you, as uſual.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: If I had not the greateſt regard imaginable for my old friend, I ſhould hate him abominably, for always beating me at backgammon. But let me conſider, now—She has ten thouſand pounds of her own. I will give her as much more, at preſent, and my whole eſtate, after my death.—No, no,—that won't be acting juſtly—Woodley may have children—They have not offended me, though their father has;—and if they ſhould be half ſo pleaſant as he was when he was a child, I ſhould love them dearly, as I once did him. But I muſt ſtrive to forget all that buſineſs, now.—Here comes Louiſa.
sp.stage: Enter Lady MARY, who keeps at a diſtance, without Sir WILLIAM's looking at her.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, child; you know, I ſuppoſe, that my hopeful nephew is totally ruined—

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why don't you come nearer? I wouldn't have all the houſe hear me.— (ſhe advances) My nephew, I tell you, is ruined.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I could not have imagined, Sir, when you did me the honour of ſending for me, that you meant to alarm or inſult me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I ſend for you! I inſult you!—That blundering Waters!—No, Madam, you are the laſt perſon in the world, except your huſband, that I ſhould think of ſending for.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: The reſpect I have for you, Sir, as Mr. Woodley's relation, muſt make it extremely painful to me to know that I am ſo diſagreeable to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Reſpect for me, Madam! I don't deſire your reſpect, nor deſerve your reſpect.— (aſide) If ſhe talks in this way, ſhe'll ſtagger my reſolution.—I wanted to ſpeak with my niece, Madam, and my blundering ſervant—

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Has brought you one that is proud of that title, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You have a title of your own, Madam.—I hate titles—and one reaſon why I never married, was becauſe I would not have my wife called my Lady.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I ſee, Sir William, that you are not inclined—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To converſe with Ladies, Madam.—I would ſpeak with Louiſa, upon buſineſs.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I ſhall no longer obtrude on you, Sir; but before I go, muſt requeſt you'll explain what you meant by ſaying that Mr. Woodley was ruined.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
She knows nothing of the matter, I find, and I cannot bear to ſhock her.—I think, Madam, you ought to underſtand that matter as well as I.—Ruined!—Why, 'tis a common phraſe, at preſent, Madam.—Dukes, Lords, and Commons, nay, the whole Nation, are ruined, Madam—'tis
quite the Ton; and I ſuppoſe that neither Mr. Woodley nor you would chuſe to be out of the faſhion.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, you'll allow that Mr. Woodley's fortune, and my rank, entitles us—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: To be ruined in good company, Madam.— (aſide.) She has touched the right key now. I'm no more afraid of her. Had ſhe fallen a-crying, I might have been ruined too.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I am ſorry to find, Sir, that your prejudices againſt Mr. Woodley and me are ſo ſtrong, that it would be in vain for us to attempt a juſtification of our conduct.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Quite ſo, indeed, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I ſhall therefore take my leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You have mine, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Shall I ſend Miſs Woodley to you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Madam, no; I'll ſend for her when I am a little more compoſed. Your ſervant—your ſervant, Madam.— [Exit Lady Mary]—Waters!—What a martyrdom has this fellow expoſed me to!—Waters!— (enter Waters)—Thou eternal blockhead, dolt, dunderhead—

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p: Does your Honour ſpeak to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No; to the door; to the window; to this table—Matter itſelf has more intelligence than thou.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Would your Honour pleaſe to have dinner ſerved? It is quite ready.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Let it wait.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Belford is below, Sir,

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll go then. What a provoking blunder!

If Belford ſhould ſucceed with my uncle, all may yet be well. Something muſt be done, and quickly too. I can no longer endure the agony of endeavouring to impoſe upon the world, and myſelf, by perſonating a borrowed character. But here ſhe comes, who innocently adds to all my ſufferings, and tips the darts of poverty with anguiſh!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: O! my dear Woodley! ſuch a trial ordeal as I have undergone! I declare I would rather be buried alive, in Dorſetſhire, than endure ſuch another tête-à-tête. He has done every thing, but beat me.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I don't comprehend you—Whom do you mean?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Nay, that's downright perverſeneſs; for I am certain there is not ſuch another creature upon earth, as your precious Uncle.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I hope you have not quarrelled with him, Lady Mary?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: No, truly; he has ſpared me that trouble, by quarrelling with me, moſt outrageouſly.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Then all my hopes in Belford are at an end. I am very ſorry you happened to come in his way.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I'm ſure ſo am I, Mr. Woodley. The interview was not of my ſeeking; and though I was as mild as a lamb, he was as rude as a bear. The deuce take his blundering ſervant for bringing me into ſuch a ſcrape!

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I ſhould hope that your regard for me would have prevented—

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p:
And ſo it did, I aſſure you; for I did not laugh, tho' he ſaid ſomething ſo ridiculous,
about your being ruined, the Nation being ruined, and all the world being ruined, that I had much ado to keep my countenance. However, I behaved very decently all the while, and even condeſcended to entreat that he would give you leave to juſtify your conduct to him.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: And did my dear Mary obtain his permiſſion?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Your earneſtneſs ſtartles me, Mr. Woodley. Of what conſequence can the old-faſhioned opinion of an obſtinate Don Choleric, who hates us both, be of to us? I wiſh he would endow an Hoſpital with his fortune, that our ſolicitude to pleaſe might end with our expectations.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Mine ſhould not, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: That muſt be as you pleaſe, Mr. Woodley; but I declare, that from this hour—

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Make no raſh vows, Madam. You know not how much you have been, or may be, indebted to Sir William.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I indebted to him! No, Mr. Woodley, that I poſitively deny.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: And ſo do I, with both my hands, and all my heart; for be the queſtion in Law, Phyſic, or Divinity, I'll pawn my life on't, that Lady Mary is right.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you for your good opinion, Mr. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: And I wager on Mr. Woodley's ſide, were it only to keep up the argument. The queſtion, then?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the queſtion?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: There are ſecrets in all families, you know, my dear Bromley.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: And it is always prudent to keep them ſo, Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Very good, very good, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Curioſity, thank heaven, is not one of my failings. 'Tis ever a mark both of ignorance and ill-breeding. I am aſtoniſhed how any one can be infected with ſuch an impertinent weakneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Yes, yes, my Dame is quite above all ſilly curioſity— (aſide.) The verieſt eaves-dropper that ever exiſted. She'll not reſt 'till ſhe has got the whole ſtory, and I ſhall have it the moment we get home.
sp.stage: Mrs. Bromley ſhews a Box of Jewels to Lady Mary.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: They are quite charming, indeed! I ſhall outblaze the Queen of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: What jewels are theſe? I hope you have not bought them, Lady Mary!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You hope I have not bought them—What an odd ſpeech, Mr. Woodley! No; I have only borrowed them, and will lend you part, if you'll go en Turc. I can ſpare enough to ornament his turban, can't I, Bromley?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Surely you don't perſiſt in making a family party, Lady Mary?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You ſhall have theſe.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Prithee, don't teize me, Lady Mary—I ſhall not go to the Maſquerade.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Don't teize me! Something extraordinary muſt have diſturbed him.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: You'll have a charming ſqueeze at your rout, Lady Mary! Not a vacant chair to be found in the whole houſe, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You flatter me. No; I believe there will hardly be any body. Do you know that I have had a hundred and ninety-one excuſes within theſe two days?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p:
Ay, but you'll have nine hundred
and ninety people, for all that. I hope Lady Sitfaſt won't come! That woman never orders her carriage till near one, tho' ſhe plagues the ſervant to call it up, every five minutes after eleven.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Then there's that poor, drooping Mrs. Henpeck, who always loſes, and ſits moaning over her loſſes, and playing the after-game, 'till the ſervants are obliged to put her out along with the candles.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: No more excuſes, I hope?

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: Dinner is ſerved, pleaſe your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Is Sir Harry Granger come?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: O, no; he has no longer the entrée here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: I'm heartily ſorry for it. No man tempers a ſallad like Sir Harry. He is a perfect compendium of the whole art of cookery, and has more good receipts in his pocket-book, than ever were publiſhed by the celebrated Hannah Glaſs.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Moſt excellent qualifications for a man of faſhion!

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: True, very true, indeed! Eating is the rage, the high ton, at preſent, and indeed is one of the moſt refined of our modern ſtudies.—Will your Ladyſhip permit me the tranſcendant honour of your fair hand?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I attend Mrs. Bromley.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: Sir WILLIAM and Mr. BELFORD at a Table, with a Bottle and Glaſſes.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I AM no drinking man myſelf, Belford; but yet I do not approve of this water ſyſtem of yours. It keeps the ſpirits too low—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: To ſay or do any thing mad or fooliſh, I grant it may. But if water does not raiſe, it never depreſſes the ſpirits. Can you ſay as much for your generous wine?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, well, I won't diſpute with you, becauſe I hate argument; and as you are an honeſt fellow, I can venture to take my glaſs chearfully in your company, tho' you don't partake of my liquor. But I'd give ſomething, ay, more than I'll mention, that you'd ſhare only one pint of claret with me, now.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I have made no vows, Sir William; and to humour a friend can eaſily diſpenſe with rules of my own making: So here's your fair niece, Louiſa Woodley, in a bumper.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Thank you, thank you, my good friend! She is a moſt excellent girl, and I like to have her toaſted by ſuch a man as you. I wiſh ſhe was well ſettled, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: There can be no doubt of her marrying to advantage. She is a fine young woman, with a fine fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
And ſo may be ſacrificed to ſome fine young man, that may ſpend her fortune in finery, as her hopeful brother has done, and leave her a beggar.
No, no,—I'll prevent that—I have thought of a match for her—Fill your glaſs, Belford!—a prudent, ſober, ſenſible man.— (aſide) I wiſh he'd take the hint.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Rare qualities, indeed, for a young man of faſhion to poſſeſs, in theſe days, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Who told you that he was a young man of faſhion? Why, Sir, there have been no men born, at leaſt, for theſe laſt thirty years—all monkies and macaronies. No Hearts of Oak, now, Belford,—all dwindled, dwindled into aſpens!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Your ſarcaſm is rather too general, my good friend. Courage is the birth-right of an Engliſhman, and while one acre of our ſoil remains, both the Oak and the Laurel will thrive on it.—We muſt not prejudge the riſing generation; and I have not the leaſt doubt but your niece will make a very proper choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: A choice! I hope ſhe has been better educated, than to have a choice, Sir. I was not conſulted in her brother's match, and you ſee the conſequence.—I ſhall diſpoſe of Louiſa in my own way.—I have a huſband now in my eye for her, Belford.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Whoever obtains Miſs Woodley, will, I dare ſay, be a very happy man.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Stick to that, my dear Belford.—Yes, yes, whoever marries Louiſa will be a very happy man, and I am extremely glad you think ſo.— (aſide) I wiſh he'd come to the point.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You know, Sir William, that I have long been acquainted with Miſs Woodley's merit.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You charm me, my dear Belford. I am glad you know her worth, and you will therefore cheriſh it.—She is mild and timid—but you'll be kind and gentle to her, even for my ſake, my good old friend.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Kind and gentle to her! and your good old friend!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, are not you my friend?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Moſt certainly.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Then why all this reiteration? If you marry Louiſa—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I marry her, Sir William!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—Did you not, this moment, allow that who ever married her, would be a very happy man? And I ſuppoſe, you can have no poſſible objection to being a very happy man, Mr. Belford?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the ſtrongeſt in the world, if my happineſs is to be purchaſed at the expence of another's miſery.—But I am wrong for being ſerious, when I am certain you do but jeſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: In the firſt place, Sir, I never ſaid any thing in jeſt, ſince I was born.—And, ſecondly, Sir, I never was more in earneſt, in the whole courſe of my life. I therefore requeſt from you a ſerious anſwer.—Jeſt, indeed! No, truly, Counſellor, I am no joker.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Why, then, Sir, I ſhould think myſelf highly honoured—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pſha, pſha, pſha—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Patience, my good friend—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir—I will have no patience with your nonſenſical compliments—none of your honours, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: In a word, then, Sir William, the diſparity of years between forty-eight and eighteen—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Is juſt nothing at all.—What need you tell her you are forty-eight?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: There will be no occaſion, I grant you—Self-evident propoſitions need no proof.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
Hark'ye, Belford, you fatigue me to death with your logic and ſophiſtry.—The point
may be reduced to two words,—Will you marry my niece, or no?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: It is a match ſo infinitely beyond my pretenſions, Sir William—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I hope I may be allowed the beſt judge in that matter, Mr. Belford.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: By no means, Sir William, your partial kindneſs towards me—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Is almoſt worn out, by your tireſome, falſe modeſty;—and, if I thought I ſhould have as much plague with Louiſa, as I have had with you, I'd renounce my project, and leave her to die an old maid.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: The propoſal is ſo highly favourable to me—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: That you conſent.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Were I certain that Miſs Woodley's inclinations—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I told you, before, that I could diſpoſe of them as I pleaſed; ſo that if you have no other objection, I ſhall carry my point, and ſettle one of my family to my entire ſatisfaction, at laſt.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: It is impoſſible that I can have any objection, if ſhe has none.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Your hand then, my dear Belford—'Tis a match.—Order your clerks to ſet about the writings directly.—Your eſtate lies in Staffordſhire, I think.—You know I add ten thouſand to her fortune.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: But ſurely, my dear Sir William, Miſs Woodley ought to be made acquainted—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, has ſhe not been acquainted with you ever ſince ſhe was born? If I miſtake not, you were preſent at her chriſtening.—The wedding ſhall be next week—The ſooner my dear girl is happily ſettled, the better.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Your kindneſs overwhelms me—but ſtill, Miſs Woodley—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Shall be made acquainted with her happineſs, this evening. I leave all the articles of ſettlement to your own honour.—I know you'll make a proper proviſion for my niece, becauſe it is poſſible you may die before her—but no pin-money, I charge you—'Tis but a prelude to alimony, believe me.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I ſhall endeavour to acquit myſelf as ſuch a generous confidence deſerves.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Hurry, hurry your clerks, and bring this happy event to a ſpeedy concluſion, my dear nephew.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I have the ſtrongeſt motives to enforce their diligence, as well as the higheſt ſenſe of my obligations to your friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No ſpeeches—haſten the buſineſs, and adieu.— [Exit Belford.]—I'll ſpeak to Jones, directly, to prepare for the wedding-dinner. She can't bear to be hurried; and I'd have every thing magnificent on that day, which I ſhall deem the happieſt of my whole life; becauſe it will be the firſt time I could ever get any of my family to know their own intereſt, and act as I would have them.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I am very glad to ſee you, my dear child.—And now what have you to ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I was informed, Sir, by my ſiſter, that you deſired to ſpeak with me, and I am therefore come to receive your commands.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, my dear, it will neither be queſtions nor commands, but croſs-purpoſes, if you keep at ſuch a diſtance as will make it impoſſible we ſhould hear one another. Come nearer, I ſay—What are you afraid of?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
So, ſo—that will do.—And now, my dear child, you can't imagine what a heavenly temper
I am in, and what favourable diſpoſitions I have towards you.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I am very happy, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: So you'll ſay, my dear, when you know all. But you muſt deſerve my kindneſs, by your frankneſs;—therefore, firſt tell me, whether you have any particular objection to matrimony?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: It is a ſubject, Sir, that I have never much thought upon.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: That's ſingular, now; for I am told that the girls of theſe days think of nothing elſe. But, luckily, there is no occaſion for your conſidering about the matter, as you have ſuch a friend as I am to conſider for you, child.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And ſo I ſhall make your mind eaſy at once, by letting you know that I have provided a huſband for you.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: (aſide.) Now, Heaven forbid!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: And ſuch a one as is not to be met with every day, I aſſure you—a man after my own heart—has not a fault, Louiſa, but that he is a water-drinker. But I won't anticipate, by telling you his name. He ſhall ſurpriſe you with it himſelf.—Why, hey!—what's the matter now? You don't ſeem at all overjoyed!—You are not hankering after a title, I hope; for, believe me, niece, if there be either happineſs or virtue left in the preſent world, they are only to be met with in the middle ranks of life. What makes you tremble ſo?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You are not unacquainted with my timidity, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I underſtand the timidity of your whole ſex— (aſide.) Doves before marriage, and Kites after.—You'll ſoon get the better of your timidity, I'll anſwer for it.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: As I am certain, Sir, that 'tis your wiſh to make me happy—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: You are right, my dear; but it muſt be my own way. Your brother's want of reſpect to my opinion, you ſee, has been his ruin, child. Don't attempt to copy him, Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: If you would but condeſcend to hear me, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, child, I know every thing already, that you would wiſh to ſay. Your obligations to me, and your modeſty, and your timidity, and your ſettlement, and all that—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I have not a thought about a ſettlement—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, well, every thing ſhall be taken care of, except a proviſion for a ſeparate maintenance. I bar that; for if you can't live happily with ſuch a huſband as I have choſen for you, I ſhould think you deſerved to ſtarve, tho' you were my niece a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: But, my dear uncle—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: But, my dear niece, don't inſiſt upon it; for a woman who thinks of ſeparation at the moment of her union, does not intend to abide by her huſband, as ſhe ought to do, 'till death do them part.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I neither think of union nor ſeparation, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Modeſt and virtuous that—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Hear me but one word, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Enough's ſaid, enough's ſaid, my dear. Here, take this bill, to provide for your dreſs. I'd have every thing handſome. The ladies are great belles in Staffordſhire; and I'd have my niece make as good an appearnace as any private gentlewoman among them. Why don't you take the bill? 'Tis for five hundred pounds, and I hope you think that ſufficient.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I have no ſort of occaſion for it, Sir; and if you would but indulge me with a moment's converſation—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Pſha, pſha, pſha,—I hate all this affected delicacy. Take money from the old man whenever you can get it. Haſten your milliners and mantua-makers, and get all your matters ready by this day ſe'nnight, for I won't have the wedding deferred an hour longer. Delays are ever dangerous.
sp.stage: (Exit, throwing the bill on the table.)

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: What, in the name of wonder, can this dear, kind, cruel uncle of mine intend for me? I almoſt doubt whether I wake or not. Married in a week, to a man perhaps I never ſaw! No, that's impoſſible—he is too good to think of ſuch an union. Poſſibly Mountfort may have applied for his conſent, before he aſked mine!—Too fond a hope, I fear.—I wiſh I could ſee Counſellor Belford; my uncle keeps no ſecret from him, and he is a friend to all our family. I'll write to him to come to me inſtantly.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. Belford, without ſeeing Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I cannot proceed on this buſineſs, in earneſt, till Sir William has had ſome conference with his niece. It is poſſible ſhe may diſlike the match, or perhaps be otherwiſe engaged—and then I ſhould become the ſtanding jeſt of all my brother Benchers. I muſt ſpeak to Sir William again.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: My good Mr. Belford, I never was ſo glad to ſee you in my whole life. I have been this moment writing to you.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You make me the happieſt of mortals, Madam.— (aſide This Brief opens well! I need not be much afraid of being laughed at now.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: There is ſomething ſo particular— (aſide I know not how to mention it—Mr. Belford, my good uncle has—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I find completed his kindneſs, and acquainted you, Madam—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: No, Sir, but as you ſhare his confidence, I muſt entreat that you'll inform me— (beſitates)

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: (aſide) Her modeſty diſtreſſes me vaſtly; but I like her the better for it! I wiſh I had a ſpeech ready.—Did not Sir William, Madam, ſay any thing of matrimony to you?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You can't imagine, Sir, how he has ſurpriſed and terrified me, by talking of my being to be married in a week.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: You might be ſurpriſed, to be ſure, Madam; but I don't ſee any occaſion for your being terrified, any more than for ſuch a violent hurry. The writings can't be properly engroſſed in that time. The Law ſeldom keeps pace with a Lover's wiſhes;—and however impatient I may be to expedite this buſineſs, you ſhall not be hurried, fair Lady, but be at liberty to name your own day.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: It ſhall be Doomſday, then—However, I thank you, Sir, for allowing me even a reprieve.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: (aſide) Hey-dey! Where ſits the wind now?—You have no abſolute averſion to marriage, I hope, Miſs Woodley?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I deſpiſe affectation, Sir, and am above diſguiſe, with an old friend like you:—I have no averſion to marriage, when I can beſtow my hand with my heart;—but I would rather die, than be ſacrificed to a frightful fordid wretch, who has trepanned my uncle out of his conſent, becauſe he deſpaired of mine, and takes me merely as an appendage to my fortune.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: (aſide) How lucky was my coming back!—But why ſhould you ſuppoſe, Madam, that your uncle would ſacrifice you to a frightful ſordid wretch? Your intended huſband is a very different kind of man, I'll aſſure you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Let him be what he will, Sir, I ſhall deteſt him.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I never thought, Miſs Woodley, that my conduct or character had in any inſtance merited your deteſtation, Madam.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Deteſt you, Mr. Belford! No, that's impoſſible!—But how are you concerned in the matter?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Not much, at preſent, Madam;—for I ſcorn to take advantage of your uncle's engagements, unleſs ratified by your conſent.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Belford!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Nay, never whimper about it. I own, I ſuſpected, from the firſt, that it was rather too good news to be true:—but don't make yourſelf unhappy, Miſs Woodley; for I would rather live and die a batchelor, than marry the fineſt woman in England, as is now the caſe (bowing), who was not equally ready to have and to hold.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Generous, worthy man!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Not more generous than prudent, Madam, on this occaſion. But, as I hope I have now deſerved your confidence, Miſs Woodley, tell me then, if you have any particular attachment, and I ſhall endeavour to ſerve you with Sir William;—though I know I ſhall, for a time, ſtand in the light of a culprit before him, by declining the honour he intended me.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You overpower me with obligations, Mr. Belford.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: No ſpeeches, my dear Madam. If I was not ſufficiently gratified by the honour of the act, no acknowledgements could make me amends for the diſappointment; ſo frankly name the happy man who is to raiſe my envy, and compleat your happineſs.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Though I think that a well-placed and mutual affection need not raiſe a bluſh upon the chaſteſt cheek, yet mine will glow when I name Colonel Mountfort.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Colonel Mountfort! I'm ſorry for it▪

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Why ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Becauſe he's a very pretty fellow, Madam, and for that reaſon may fall within your uncle's chapter of coxcombs, and prevent his conſent.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Then I ſhall never give mine to marry any man elſe.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: That's ſomewhat in the Knight's own ſtile, Miſs Woodley. But I heartily wiſh you ſucceſs, and ſhall ſhew myſelf a warmer Friend than a Lover, by uſing my beſt pleadings in my rival's ſuit.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Accept my warmeſt thanks, my good old friend.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Ay, ay,—I knew ſhe would always think of me as her old friend.
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Mr. WOODLEY's. A Dining-Room.
Mr. WOODLEY and Mr. BROMLEY at a Table, with a Dice-Box.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I'll play no more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure, my dear friend, luck has run confoundedly againſt you; but I never ſaw you give out for ſuch a trifling loſs, before.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Seven hundred pounds is no trifle, Mr. Bromley!

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: A trifle, indeed, to a perſon of your immenſe fortune!

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: You have made a falſe eſtimate of my circumſtances. I am rather a diſtreſſed man, at preſent, Mr. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: (aſide) Are you ſo? Then 'tis time for me to take care of myſelf.—You ſurpriſe me vaſtly! Diſtreſſed did you ſay?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I hate to repeat it; but 'tis ſo true, that I had ſome thoughts of applying to your friendſhip, to extricate me out of my preſent difficulties, Mr. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Command me, command me, my dear Woodley! Every thing that poor Bob Bromley has in the world— (aſide) except his money,—is at your ſervice.—But let us clear as we go—ſettle our little matters firſt—juſt ſet your name to this paper—or will you take another throw, my friend, and let it be double or quit?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: For ſhame, Woodley!—at hazard in your own houſe! I thought you had enough of that at Clubs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Play among friends is wrong, very wrong, I confeſs, Colonel; but one can't be always grave and wiſe.—Come, my dear Woodley, let us make an end of our buſineſs—the pen, or the box, my dear boy?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Deſperate ſituations require deſperate remedies.—Give me the box— (they throw) Damn the dice!

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: 'Tis double, now, you know, my unlucky friend; which makes upon the whole exactly the ſum of ſeven thouſand three hundred and fifty-four pounds, including the dear Lady Mary's trifling debt to Mrs. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: True, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Well, I have brought a bond with me, and when I have filled up the blanks, if you pleaſe we'll perfect it in the next room.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: With all my heart.— (aſide.) Sure never man was ſo completely unfortunate! Never, by Heaven, will I touch a die again!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Then I give you joy of your loſſes; for I
know you are too much a man of honour to break your vow.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Gameſters, like lovers, you know, Colonel—And after all, now, this is but matter of form between friends and men of honour, like you and me.—Don't you think ſo, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I conſider all compulſive obligations between men as a diſgrace to human nature. But while there are ſuch things as knaves in the world, Mr. Bromley, we muſt ſubmit to the mean ſecurities of bars and bonds. But between men of honour, as you ſay—

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Certainly, my dear Sir, men of honour are—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Too often the dupes of knaves, Mr. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: I don't like him.—We'll talk over the affair you hinted at in the next room. Command me, on all occaſions—ever—ever at your ſervice. But I muſt attend the ladies. The ladies and the coffee are powerful attractions to me. You'll follow me, I preſume, Colonel?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Yes, with pleaſure, through my whole regiment, with a drum at your heels. I am perſuaded, Woodley, that fellow is a knave, and I wiſh you would exclude both him and his flaunting wife from your's and Lady Mary's ſociety. I can't conceive why you are ſo partial to them.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: The great civilities we received from them, at Spa, firſt attached my wife to Mrs. Bromley, who was there in the firſt ſets, and even in London, where people are more nice. She keeps very good company, I aſſure you, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
You'll pardon me, Woodley!—She is ſeldom ſeen in public but with ſome damaged Dowager of Quality, who would be excluded from ſociety if her title did not ſerve as a herald to make way for her Ladyſhip.—But enough of them! I am come to ſpeak to you on a much more intereſting ſubject,
and to prove—what, however, I cannot doubt—your friendſhip for me.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Be aſſured, my dear Mountfort—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: I am ſo—you need not make profeſſions;—therefore, with the frankneſs of a ſoldier, I venture to aſk the higheſt proof of your regard, by conſenting to make the fair Louiſa mine.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: My ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You ſeem to heſitate, Mr. Woodley! My fortune is—

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: As unexceptionable as your character, Colonel; and as I truly love Louiſa, and ſhould rejoice in her happineſs—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You conſent to mine. Is it ſo, my friend?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I know not how to anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You alarm me extremely, Mr. Woodley! For heaven's ſake, ſpeak out!—What can be your objections?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: None in the world, to you; but circumſtanced as I am at preſent, it would involve me in the greateſt difficulties, to be called upon ſo ſuddenly for ten thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That ſhall not be the caſe, Woodley. I ſhould think even Louiſa too dearly purchaſed, at the expence of diſtreſſing you. When I aſked for your ſiſter's hand, I did not demand her purſe; nor ſhall I accept the one, 'till I have ſigned a releaſe for the other.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Mountfort, that muſt not, ſhall not be! I never will accept of ſuch a ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hark-ye, Woodley! A ſoldier's character ſhould be uniform; and if there could be one who was not liberal, I ſhould ſuſpect his courage to be of the mere animal kind.
