My fortune is ſufficiently ample; and I would as ſoon mount my charger, cry ſtand and deliver, as take money I don't want, from a friend who does.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Your generoſity, Colonel—

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Is of too ſelfiſh a nature to merit praiſe; for I feel here (laying his hand to his heart) that the true luxury of fortune lies more in giving, than in ſpending.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I will not leſſen it, by offering thanks. But have you opened your trenches before the Knight of the Caſtle yet? (pointing to the middle door) He uſed to ſpeak well of you, and his opinion is of ſome conſequence in this buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: My ſentiments are even with the good old Knight's, I aſſure you. I eſteem his good qualities, and do not diſlike even his foibles, as they are truly natural and unſophiſticate. But there, perhaps, you may ſee me play the uſurer, like any Jew. He may double or treble Louiſa's fortune, without the leaſt impediment from any ſcruple or modeſty of mine.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: When do you purpoſe to make the eſſay?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: As ſoon as poſſible; for 'till I have paid the proper reſpect due to him, I do not think myſelf entitled to throw myſelf at Louiſa's feet.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: May ſucceſs attend you, my generous friend!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Fie, Woodley—no more of that!—But adieu.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: AND ſo that was all?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Every word, I aſſure you. But we ſhall ſoon make it up, for ours are but lovers' quarrels.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Lovers! talk of love after four years marriage! Believe me, Lady Mary, 'tis all a farce.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: No, my dear Mrs. Bromley, I cannot give you credit againſt the feelings of my own heart. I love Mr. Woodley, and I am firmly perſuaded that he has a ſincere affection for me, notwithſtanding the little peeviſhneſs of his behaviour to-day, which I own makes me apprehend that ſomething muſt have ruffled him extremely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: How did you like his peremptory reſolve, of paſſing the whole ſummer in Dorſetſhire?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Not at all, I confeſs; 'tis frightful to think of it—though there is a tolerable neighbourhood—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Of empty houſes.—No creature ſtays at their family ſeats, now-a-days, unleſs it be ſome antiquated Dowager, who, like an old Gothic corner cupboard, remains fixed to the freehold.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I vow I won't go into the country—'tis quite mauvais ton—except you'll come with us; and then we'll fly about to all the bathing-places, and give a maſquerade at one of them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I ſhould like to paſs a few weeks ſo, well enough;—and, indeed, my dear, you'll be quite forgotten, if you don't do ſomething in that way. But are you ſure that Mr. Woodley would like it? for I muſt ſay, though I aſk your pardon, Lady Mary, he is dull—abſolutely dull, indeed, my dear.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Why, I own, of late he has been rather gloomy;—but he is vaſtly good-natured, and never before refuſed any requeſt of mine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: That may be:—but had Mr. Bromley talked to me in the ſame manner—

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You would have loved him juſt as well as you do now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: You are admirable at gueſſing, my dear;—for as that ſame romantic notion of love never was the band of our connexion—

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You ſtartle me, Mrs. Bromley. Marriage without love muſt ſurely be a ſtate of the greateſt unhappineſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: No, I don't feel in the leaſt unhappy.—Convenience is the beſt matrimonial cement, and keeps many couples together for years, whoſe love did not out-laſt the honey-moon.—But theſe are myſteries, into which you ſeem not yet initiated.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall never know them by experience.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: My dear ſiſter— (ſees Mrs. Bromley) I thought you were alone; I had ſomething in particular to tell you.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You alarm me vaſtly, Louiſa!—What is the matter, my dear? You know I keep no ſecrets from Mrs. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Another time, Lady Mary. Family affairs—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p:
Pray, my dear, make no ſtranger of me!— (aſide) I hope Mountfort has jilted he •
▪ I die to know.—Has the gallant Colonel deſerted, my dear?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Colonel Mountfort, Madam, is no way concerned in the preſent queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Then I would not give ſixpence for the whole ſtory.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You look diſtreſſed, Louiſa!—What can have happened? I'm all impatience.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Though I had rather be excuſed, Lady Mary, yet as you preſs ſo earneſtly to know, my Uncle—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Pſha!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Has inſiſted on my marrying—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Not himſelf, hope?

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Giddy creature! I Whom, my dear Louiſa?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Counſellor Belford.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: And is that all? I think it a monſtrous good match.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Monſtrous, indeed!—Why, he's fifty, at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Fifty! fiddle-ſtick! What does that ſignify? He is rich enough for threeſcore; and money, money, my dear, qualifies all diſproportions.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: This is by much too ſerious a ſubject for jeſting, Mrs. Bromley.—But Sir William is not your ſole Guardian, Louiſa; and your brother, I am certain, will never conſent to ſacrifice you to his uncle's caprice.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I would not, on any account, my dear ſiſter, have my brother oppoſe Sir William in any thing, as he is already but too much offended with him. Beſides, I am in hopes that there will not be any occaſion for his interpoſing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: She's coming round, I find.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Bromley, Madam, has ſent the carriage, and deſires to ſpeak with you, at home, immediately.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I'm glad of the releaſe.—What now can he poſſibly want with me? But I am all obedience, though it breaks my heart to leave you. But I ſhall return quickly, before any one ſits down to Loo.—And ſo, my dear, (to Louiſa) I leave you to ſettle your important matters, which ſhould be ſoon determined, were you my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Thank Heaven, I am not!—She is levity itſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Her lightneſs, Louiſa, extends no farther than her manners:—her morals are irreproachable; and when the mind is untainted, its gaiety, like a coloured trimming to a grave ſuit, ſerves only to enliven it.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You are too partial, ſiſter; for I much fear that you will one day diſcover Mrs. Bromley's manners and morals to be both of a piece.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: No more upon the ſubject, at preſent!—and in truth I wonder how you can have ſpirits to talk of any thing elſe but your own melancholy ſituation.—Married to Belford! to your Grandfather!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I ſhould be ſad, indeed, if ſuch a marriage was to take place;—but my Intended has generouſly conſented to break off the match, at my requeſt, and to ſcreen me from Sir William's diſpleaſure, at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Then the old Barriſter is charming, and I think I could be a little in love with him myſelf. But I cannot ſubmit to this new inſult from Sir William! What could he mean by diſpoſing of you without deigning to conſult Mr. Woodley? I ſhall inſiſt upon an explanation of his conduct.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I again intreat you, Lady Mary, not to involve my brother farther with Sir William—you do not know the conſequences.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I am quite weary of all this temporizing, Louiſa; and as you are ſafe on ſhore, you muſt allow me to guide the helm for myſelf, at preſent.—You'll permit me, at leaſt, to acquaint Mr. Woodley with his uncle's contemptuous neglect of him in this matter, which I ſhall go and do directly.
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Sir WILLIAM's Apartments.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, for once, Waters, I will acknowledge myſelf the happieſt man in England.

sp.speaker: Waters.
sp.p: I am proud to hear that your Honour is ſo well pleaſed.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I am pleaſed, and I won't be pleaſed alone—they ſhall be pleaſed too!—They ſhall have a noble ſervice of plate!—Louiſa deſerves every thing—ſhe behaved like an angel! I thought I ſhould have had more trouble with her; but though it be ſtrange, it is certainly true, that all girls like to be married.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Colonel Mountfort, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I ſhall be glad to ſee him.—Wa't on him up, Waters. (Exeunt Waters and Servant) The Colonel is a very good young man, as young men go, at preſent—but nothing to compare to what his father was.
I am very glad to ſee you, my young friend. Set chairs, Waters.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you, Sir William, and happy to perceive by your looks that all inquiries after your health muſt be ſuperfluous.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir!—I fancy, indeed, I do look tolerably well, for ſerenity of mind goes a great way towards clearing up the countenance; and I do not know when my ſpirits have ever been ſo harmonized, as at this moment.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: How fortunate!—May I flatter myſelf, Sir William, that the preſent happy temper of your mind will aſſiſt my ſuit, and render you propitious!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Propitious! Nonſenſe.—You are an idle young rogue!—With ſuch a noble fortune as yours—But I won't ſcold, now.—You have been on the Turf, I ſuppoſe, or fleeced at the Gaming-table?—But I hope the Terra Firma is ſafe. I ſhould be grieved to ſee my old friend's eſtate in the hands of knaves or ſharpers.—What ſum do you want? I know you to be a man of honour.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You quite amaze me, Sir, by ſuſpicions which, I will be bold to ſay, are unworthy both of Sir William Woodley and me. I am no gambler, Sir, nor have I diſſipated the noble inheritance derived from my anceſtors.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I am heartily glad of it, Sir!—I aſk your pardon, young man.— (aſide) What the deuce, then, can he want from me?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If I were ſo unfortunately weak, as you for a moment ſeemed to imagine, the reſpect I bear you, would have prevented my applying to you upon ſuch an occaſion, as your good opinion, Sir, is of the greateſt conſequence to my happineſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: There you are wrong, Colonel;—you had much better apply to me, than to any one elſe.—I am no cent. per cent. man—I never received a ſhilling intereſt from any friend in my life; and I have my doubts whether I ſhould even take it from the Funds, now that the Nation is ſo poor.—But come, Colonel, if you don't want money, in what other way can I poſſibly ſerve you? I have no intereſt at Court.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You have an intereſt, Sir, in what is far dearer to me than either wealth or preferment:—your lovely niece, Louiſa, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Thank Heaven, ſhe is better diſpoſed of!

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You pauſe!—Do not keep me on the rack, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I was only recollecting myſelf.—Am much obliged to you, Sir, for the honour—I think that's the phraſe—you intend my niece; but ſhe's married, Sir.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Married, Sir William!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,—married, and ſettled in the country.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This raillery is rather cruel, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: I never joke, Sir.—I have paſſed my word that ſhe ſhall be married this day ſe'nnight; and if all the Emperors, Kings, Princes, and Potentates in Europe, nay the Great Mogul himſelf, were to demand her in marriage, William Woodley would not forfeit his promiſe: ſo that married ſhe is, to all intents and purpoſes, my gay Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: And has Miſs Woodley conſented, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Ay, to be ſure; I force no-body.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Confuſion!—Impoſſible, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why ſhould you think ſo? She is a modeſt, dutiful girl. It would be hard, indeed, if I was to have no comfort in my family. But don't be diſheartened, Colonel! Many a gallant ſoldier has met with a repulſe, before now.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: If you could conceive the tenderneſs of my affection for Miſs Woodley, Sir, you would not treat my ſufferings ſo ſlightly.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: It may be a diſappointment, to be ſure, Sir, for ſhe is a fine young woman, I confeſs; but my friend has her, Sir, and you muſt think of her no more.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: It is not in my power to obey your injunction.— (aſide) I wiſh it were, falſe and ungrateful girl!—But pray, Sir, who is the envied man ſo doubly bleſſed in your friendſhip and Miſs Woodley's love?

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: That's a ſecret, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That, I think, I have a right to know, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What! you want to exerciſe your valour a little—ſa, ſa, ſa,—by challenging your rival? But keep your proweſs for the common foe: we cannot ſpare a ſoldier, at preſent, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: This treatment is unlike yourſelf, Sir William. But Miſs Woodley, I ſuppoſe, will inform me;—I preſume ſhe is not bound to keep the ſecret.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: There you are wrong again, my young hero; for ſhe really is bound by the ſtrongeſt of all poſſible ties—the not knowing it.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: You cannot now be ſerious, Sir; and I will try if I have yet power enough over Louiſa's heart to make her ſo—for I will know my rival. Adieu, Sir William!

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Colonel Huff-Cap. What a hot-brained boy! I am doubly glad Louiſa has eſcaped him:—I would have no paſſionate man in the family, but myſelf. How lucky 'tis that Louiſa does not know her huſband's name!—Women ſhould ever be kept in ignorance, to prevent miſchief. I have conducted this buſineſs moſt admirably!—I have ſome doubts, however, whether my nephew ſhould not be made acquainted with it; but he does not deſerve my confidence, and he ſhan't vex me now.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. BELFORD. Sir WILLIAM runs and embraces him.
sp.p: Are all things going on briſkly and cleverly, as they ſhould do, my dear nephew?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: The ſwifteſt bowl does not always hit the jack, Sir William; and "fair and ſoftly" is an eſtabliſhed maxim in the Law.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Well, well, we muſt ſubmit; but I hope you'll uſe as much diſpatch as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Diſpatch is a term, Sir, not to be found in any Law Dictionary that I know of; and I fancy it will be a long time before the matters you talk of will be diſpatched.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, ſurely you have a mind to try my temper, with your fair and ſoftly! But if you knew as much as I do, you would, perhaps, think it worth while to mend your pace a little; for many things fall out between the cup and lip, Mr. Belford.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: So you'll find preſently.—The moſt material point in this important affair does not appear to be yet adjuſted.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Now—what can he mean?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: There can be no marriage without the conſent of parties; and I don't find that Miſs Woodley—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: If I was not in the moſt heavenly temper, you would put me in a rage. Have I not told you, Sir, that ſhe had no conſent, no choice, but what I pleaſe to give? And in twenty years acquaintance, have you ever known me ſay an untruth, Sir? My niece is all compliance and gentleneſs; and you'll be a very happy man, my dear nephew.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I ſhould be unworthy of happineſs, if I could enjoy it on ſuch terms, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, Belford?—Your head ſeems to be turned with your good fortune, and you want to turn mine. No man that is unworthy can be happy—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: In ſhort, Sir William—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
Ay, ay, that's the thing—now you talk ſenſe! I like in ſhort—ſtick to that, my friend. If
you want more clerks, don't value expence, I'll clear all coſts—You know I hate the Law's delay.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: No law, but that of honour, has any thing to do in this caſe, Sir William; and however irkſome the taſk, I muſt beg you will permit me to undeceive you.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Then you acknowledge you have deceived me? I am thunder-ſtruck!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: No, my good friend—'tis you that have deceived yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Your propoſition is falſe, Sir. I never deceived myſelf, nor any one elſe, ſince I was born, Sir. I ſcorn and abhor deceit, Mr. Belford. But come, Sir, let me know what all this round-about tends to? Deſpiſe the chicanery of your profeſſion, and ſpeak as if you was a witneſs on the table—not a Lawyer at the bar, Sir.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I fear I ſhall rather appear a criminal at the bar to you, at preſent, Sir William.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: What, then, you are married, I ſuppoſe?—have a wife already? Nay, don't ſmile, Sir, there is no joke in this matter; and you ought to have been hanged, if you had married my niece.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I think ſo too, though not upon the account you mention, as I give you my honour I have no wife; and if I continue in my preſent mood, may venture to ſay that I never ſhall have one.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Mighty well, mighty ill, Mr. Belford! You have rewarded my ſincere friendly attachment—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: With true gratitude, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Don't offer to ſay ſo. What! to ſpurn my niece with twenty thouſand pounds! Let me tell you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: That ſhe is much too good for me.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Why really I begin to think ſo.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I rejoice, therefore, my dear friend—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p:
No, Sir, don't rejoice. I am not your friend, nor ever will be your friend. You have
broke my heart—fruſtrated all my ſchemes—diſappointed my niece.—Poor girl, I feel for her!—Young minds are eaſily broken by grief.—You will have much to anſwer for on her account, I aſſure you, Mr. Belford.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I ſhould have much more to anſwer for to Miſs Woodley, Sir William, if I did not decline the match.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Decline! Zounds, Sir, I won't bear ſo contemptuous an expreſſion!— (aſide.) I wiſh I had not been quite ſo peremptory with the Colonel.—If I could bring myſelf to unſay what I have once uttered, I would give Louiſa to Colonel Mountſort, to vex you.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I agree with you, Sir William, that it would be a more ſuitable match.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Don't agree with me, Mr. Belford, I won't ſuffer it.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Allow me at leaſt to ſay—

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: No, Sir, I won't allow you to ſay any thing, but yes, or no, to this ſimple queſtion: Do you accept, or reject, my niece?

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: The phraſe is rather too ſtrong, Sir; but I have already told you, that upon mature conſideration, I decline the honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.p: Confound your honour, and your conſideration too!—And now, Sir, I decline any further converſation, connection, or correſpondence, with you; and ſo, Sir, I am—no—I am not, your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: His rage will ſoon ſubſide, and we ſha • l be as good friends as ever. I am glad his reſentment is entirely pointed at me, as 'tis probable, that to make his niece amends for the loſs of a huſb • nd ſhe did not like, he may give her one ſhe does:—and ſo ends, exactly as it ſhould, the matr • monial ſchemes of an Old Batchelor!
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Mr. BROMLEY's. A Dining-Room.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I wiſh you would defer it till tomorrow! It will otherwiſe break up the aſſembly, and make a monſtrous buſtle in the family.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley
sp.p: A fig for the aſſembly, and the buſtle, too! No, no, my ſweet ſimpleton, buſineſs of ſome kinds brook no delay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: You have no right to complain of my ſimplicity, Mr. Bromley. It is thro' me that you get this money from the Woodleys.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Money, child! I have never touched above a thouſand pounds of their caſh yet. This piece of paper is all I have got for ſpending my time with a dull fool, and endeavouring to perſuade him that he was a Solomon, and his ſilly wife the Queen of Sheba. But I muſt be paid for my attendance and trouble, and in a few minutes I ſhall convert this manuſcript into the ſum of ſeven thouſand three hundred and fifty-three pounds, with coſts—coſts muſt be added.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I can have no objection to your being paid for your time and trouble, my dear. All I deſire is, that you may not lay on the execution 'till to-morrow. Let us devote this evening to pleaſure, my dear Brommy. I am to play gold Loo to-night, and I have a certain preſentiment that I ſhall win conſiderably.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: As to your winning, I believe you are pretty ſecure in that point. You don't leave much to chance, I imagine, my dove. But tho' you might win, I ſhall loſe conſiderably, if this bond be not put in force this very night. I have been with Woodley's attorney, Mr. Fleece'em, a very honeſt man, and for a ſmall token of friendſhip, he has informed me, that there will be ſix executions in the houſe to morrow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Six executions! Nay, then, they are done up, indeed, and it does not ſignify much keeping any further terms with them. Yet I ſtill wiſh you would poſtpone this ugly buſineſs, 'till we are gone to the maſquerade. Poor Lady Mary! it will be a ſad diſappointment to her, not to ſhew her finery.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Now you talk of finery, here, look at theſe!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Let me ſee! They are Lady Mary's ear-rings!

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: No; they were, my ſweet innocent!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: But how came you by them? She told me they were gone to be new-ſet.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: Aſk no queſtions, but take them, and think yourſelf happy in ſuch a provident huſband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Thank you, my dear Brommy! They are beautiful, indeed!—I have long wiſhed for them, I confeſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: I muſt go and expedite this buſineſs directly. Don't be frightened, dove, when the Bailiffs come in. They'll add to Lady Mary's ſqueeze, you know.—But take a little hartſhorn in your pocket:—it will be proper for you to faint, I think.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Never fear my acting properly.—But the carriage is at the door, and I have twenty places to call at. Shall I ſet you down at your lawyer's, to ſave my dear the fatigue of walking?

sp.speaker: Mr. Bromley.
sp.p: How happy am I in ſuch a diſcreet, tender wife!— (aſide) A diſſembling jade!—Come, dove.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I follow, my dear Brommy.— (aſide.) Hateful wretch!

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: SCENE, An Anti-chamber, opening into a Drawing-room.
FORWARD, with a Pencil and Pocket-book. A Foot man in the Drawing-room, placing Card-Tables for a Rout.

sp.speaker: FORWARD.
sp.p: FOUR gold Loo tables, with Monſters—Four p • und four!—Two at half-crowns! Thruſt them to the lower end of the room, James; they are ſeldom worth more than twelve ſhillings a piece.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Where ſhall I fix the Whiſt tables, Mr. Forward?

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: Damn the Whiſkers! Even the gold players never make it worth a gentleman's while to ſnuff their candles. I wiſh the Parliament would put down all ſneaking games!—A man can neither win or loſe a fortune with any degree of credit at them. No—Pharo, Pharo's the ſport.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Is this a Pharaoh's table, Mr. Forward?

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: No; but ſet that in the center, in the beſt place in the room. That's a Macao-table, and • ome of the birds, I fancy, will be picked pretty bare that play at it—Five pound five.—Do you hear, James? The moment the company's gone, pack up all the cards and candles, whether uſed or not, and carry them to my room:—I may have occaſion for them, if I ſhould ſee company while I am out of place.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: What, you leave us a few packs to make merry with in the Servants Hall, Mr. Forward? I likes a game at All • ours, dea • ly.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: Why, ſervants ſhould have their amuſements, as well as their betters, James; ſo you may ſtrip the Whiſt-tables for your own uſe. The Dons always take ſnuff, and fully their cards confoundedly.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Thank. you, thank you, Mr. Forward! Muſt I carry up the candles to your room that mayn't be lighted?

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: Certainly; the others will only ſerve for my bed-chamber, or to dreſs by. I deteſt tallow.

sp.speaker: James.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll do as I'm bid.— (aſide) What a thief it is! and as great a Jew to a poor fellow-ſervant, as if he was not the ſame fleſh and blood!

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: I ſhall make about twelve pieces packing penny. I wiſh my maſter may win to-night, as I ſhall call upon him for my wages to-morrow: and, to do him juſtice, he is always ready to pay, when he has it. The Funds are low at preſent, and a prudent man ſhould not ſuffer his money to lie dead, eſpecially in ſuch hands where it may be buried, too.
sp.stage: Enter Lady MARY and Mr. WOODLEY.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Let the ices be brought before eleven, Forward, as I wiſh the aſſembly to break up early. Are the bouquets come from the King's Road? Let there be a profuſion of rofes in all the rooms: they are delicious, at this •• aſon.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip ſhall be obeyed— (aſide) for the laſt time by your Ladyſhip's moſt humble.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Your indifference upon this occaſion really amazes me, Mr. Woodley! I thought you loved your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I do, moſt tenderly, and ſhall therefore rejoice at ſeeing her under the protection of a worthy man.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Bleſs me! is there nothing but worth to be conſid • red, in matrimony? no allowance to be made for liking? I vow, if you had been fifty times as worthy as you are, I would never have married you, if you had not been agreeable, alſo.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Sweet flatterer!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: But as the match is not to take place, his being agreeable or not is of no conſequence, now.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I don't comprehend you.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You don't chooſe to comprehend me, Mr. Woodley. But ſtill I muſt ſay, that the indignity of Sir William's preſuming to diſpoſe of your ſiſter without your conſent, is not to be endured.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: You are miſinformed, my dear. Mountfort aſked my conſent, before he applied to Sir William—I did not ſee you ſince.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Mountfort is quite out of the preſent queſtion, I tell you, Mr. Woodley.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: You rave, my dear!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: One of us does, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I am not mad, yet, Madam—though I have enough to make me ſo.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: This is too much, Mr. Woodley. Every one takes notice of your behaviour to me, of late; and wonder how I bear it.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: (looking gravely at her) Did you know what I bear—

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: From me, Mr. Woodley?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Not from, but for, you, Mary.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You terrify me! Explain your meaning, I intereat you.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: It will too ſoon ceaſe to be a myſtery.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Then, do not let me be the laſt to know it.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Could every pang I now endure, be doubled to ſave you from the ſhock which you muſt feel, I'd bear them all, without complaining. But ruin comes on apace! and that you muſt ſhare it aggravates my diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Ungenerous Woodley! to think I would ſhrink from any miſery that attends on you! But ſpeak your meaning clearly—ſuſpence is torture—what miſery awaits us?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Our fortune's gone, my Mary!—We are undone!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Gone! Not all—my jointure ſtill is left.—Diſpoſe of that, and let me go into retirement with you. With pleaſure I'll renounce all the fantaſtic gaieties of life, and find true happineſs in your ſociety.

sp.speaker: Woodley
sp.p: Your nobleneſs of mind but adds to my diſtreſs.—Your jointure! No, I will live a beggar, all my days, rather than leave you one, when I muſt leave you. Somewhat may yet be done to ſave us from deſtruction. I have a dependence on Mr. Bromley's friendſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: So have I;—but we muſt be our own friends, my dear.—I will go into Dorſetſhire, immediately. Let us diſcharge hal • our ſervants, and become patterns of oeconomy and conjugal happineſs.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Generous, charming woman! Happineſs muſt attend you, every where.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: 'Tis the inſeparable companion of an upright heart; and my dear Woodley ſhall ſoon be convinced from my conduct, that chearfulneſs can ſurvive gaiety, and true love make ample amends for the loſs of fortune.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Your ſenſe and virtue have removed the heavieſt weight that hung upon my hear • .

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Then clear your brow, my d • ar, and let us act the laſt ſcene of the farce with the ſame ſpirit as the firſt.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Colonel Mountfort, Sir.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Shew him into my dreſſing-room—I'll wait on him inſtantly.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Don't let even Colonel Mountfort perceive your dejection, my dear Woodley. We ſhould, in kindneſs to our friends, conceal our ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: If Mountfort has ſucceeded with my uncle, Louiſa's happineſs will lighten my diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I have not time to aſk an explanation of this matter, now.—But let me again intreat you to be chearful:—ſomething tells me that our ſituation is not ſo bad as you imagine. Let us not anticipate misfortune:—'tis always too ſoon to be wretched.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I will exert my utmoſt power, my dear, to emulate your fortitude.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p:
My fortitude! Ah Woodley! little doſt thou know the perturbation here.—Ruin comes on apace!—The ſhock was ſudden and ſevere; but 'twas my love, not reſolution, bore me through it.—And now let me collect myſelf a little, and try, by Reaſon's ſtandard, the value of thoſe joys which I reſign.—Dreſs! Won't my little perſon look as well in a plain ſilk, as in all this finery? Vanity ſays, Yes.—Grandeur—what is it? A magnificent ſide-board, a train of uſeleſs ſervants, gay furniture, crouded rooms, and blazing lights, which but oppreſs the ſpirits, without affording enjoyment. Elegance is not confined to ſtate: her handmaid Neatneſs ſhall preſide at our board, and render our rural fare delicious.—Operas! Ranelagh! Plays! Maſquerades! Aſſemblies! Company! ay, there's the rub! Society! dear Society! I ſhall not find, a Mrs. Bromley in Dorſetſhire; but I ſhall have my Woodley there, and my endeavours not to let him ſee I grieve,
will ſoon make me ceaſe to do ſo. My reſolution's fixed—I'll acquaint Louiſa with it inſtantly,
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Mr. WOODLEY's Dreſſing-room.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Upon my honour, Colonel, I am as unable to fathom Sir William's meaning, as you can be. I am certain that no perſon ever propoſed to me for Louiſa, but yourſelf, and ſhe could not poſſibly give her conſent, before it was aſked.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: This aſſurance has revived my hopes a little; but 'tis impoſſible my heart can be at eaſe, till your ſiſter has pronounced my doom.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: If ſhe conſults her own heart, Mountfort, you will not, I fancy, have much reaſon to complain of her ſentence. But as ſhe is the only Oedipus that can expound this riddle, let us apply to her for the explanation.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: You prevent my wiſhes, for you have an undoubted right to make the enquiry.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Tell my ſiſter I deſire to ſpeak with her, immediately.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: How my heart throbs, at her approach!

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: For ſhame, my gallant friend!

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: O Woodley! when all one's happineſs is ſtaked on the turn of a die, who would not tremble when he ſtood the caſt?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Miſs Woodley, Sir, has juſt ſent to let Sir William know ſhe wiſhes to pay her reſpects to him:—at her return ſhe will wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Inhuman girl! She trifles with my anxiety—perhaps rejoices in it.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Lovers are of all beings the moſt irrationa. I'd hazard my life that Louiſa has never heard of your propoſal to Sir William, and of courſe can know nothing of your anxiety.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: She will be ſoon acquainted with both. But have not you informed her?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: No, on my honour; I have not ſeen her ſince you left me.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Your coolneſs on this ſubject, Mr. Woodley, by no means accords with my impatience.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: You wrong me, Mountfort. Be aſſured, that your union with Louiſa is an object my heart is ſet on; but that heart is torn to pieces, at preſent.—I cannot ſpeak—Louiſa never ſtays long with her uncle—ſhe will return in a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: They will be years to me.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Let us meet her then, before ſhe goes into the drawing-room.
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Sir WILLIAM's Apartment.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Poor child! I am very ſorry ſhe is coming—I know not what excuſe to make for Belford—I fear it will be a grievous diſappointment to her.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I come, Sir, moſt joyfully to tell you ſomething that I am ſure will give you pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir William,
sp.p: My poor dear! and I have ſomething to tell you, that I am ſure will give you pain.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I am ſo much rejoiced at preſent, that there are but very few things that could render me unhappy.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: So much the worſe—the ſhock will be the greater! I ſhall never have the courage to tell her.—The ſuddenneſs of this event, Louiſa—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Do you know it, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Ay, but too well, my dear.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You quite ſurpriſe me, Sir! It is not above five minutes, ſince it was determined.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis more than that—above half an hour. But though matters have taken an unexpected turn, I would not have you fret, or grieve, child!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: So far from it, Sir, that I am quite rejoiced, and flattered myſelf that you would be ſo too, as I know it is a point you have long ſet your heart upon;—and I muſt do Lady Mary the juſtice to declare the plan was intirely her own.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Lady Mary! I gueſſed as much.—How did ſhe dare to thwart my ſchemes?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Dear Sir, have you not always wiſhed that my brother and ſiſter ſhould live in Dorſetſhire? and now that Lady Mary has, of her own accord, determined to quit London, you ſeem offended.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Softly, ſoftly, child; don't hurry me!—For once in my life, I perceive I am left behind.— (aſide) So, I find ſhe knows nothing of Belford, and that work is all to do, yet.—Go on, my dear! Lady Mary, you ſay—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Has, unſolicited by any one, reſolved to give up all the gaiety and diſſipation of this town, and remain in Dorſetſhire till my brother's affairs are intirely retrieved.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: She'll not return in a hurry, then, I doubt.—I am glad of it, my dear, for your ſake, as well as your brother's:—air and exerciſe will be of great uſe to you.— (aſide) I'm afraid ſhe'll ſtand in need of them, when ſhe is acquainted with her miſfortune.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: But, my good, dear uncle, won't you give Lady Mary credit for her prudence? and won't you permit my brother and ſiſter to take leave of you, before they go?

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: I hate all forms and ceremonies, child!—They have had my leave to go into the country, theſe three years paſt; and I am leſs diſpleaſed with your ſiſter, for her prudent reſolution. And ſo, at your requeſt, my dear, you may all breakfaſt with me before you ſet out to-morrow.— (aſide) I'll defer acquainting her till then, with Belford's behaviour.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I don't believe, Sir, that they can ſet out ſo immediately; but I am certain they will not defer a moment to accept your kind invitation, on that account.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Stop, child, ſtop! I won't have them come to me, till the very hour they are going. If I were to ſee your brother often, I might be weak enough to grow fond of him again; ſo don't let him come, I charge you, 'till his boots are on. I have trouble enough on my hands for others, already. You don't know what I ſuffer on your account, Louiſa, at this moment. But you ſhall know all about it, when you are ſetting off for Dorſetſhire.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I wiſh I dare venture to make the good man's mind eaſy, with regard to me.—As I am perfectly reſigned to your commands, Sir, on every occaſion, I hope I ſhall never give you cauſe for any real trouble.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: There now, ſhe'll break my heart with her mildneſs!—I hope for your own ſake you'll be reſigned, my dear. But go, child, and tell your brother and Lady Mary, that I ſhall be glad to ſee them on the morning they are ſetting out; but not before, upon any account whatever.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I rejoice to be the meſſenger of ſuch glad tidings; for if he ſees my brother, I am certain he will ſerve him.
sp.stage: SCENE, a Drawing-room. Card-tables, with Company at Play.
Lady MARY, LOUISA, Mr. BELFORD, Colonel MOUNTFORT.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Whiſt.
sp.p: Fifty pieces on the rubber!

sp.speaker: 2d Whiſt.
sp.p: A bet, my Lord.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: A Pam fluſh!

sp.speaker: 2d Loo.
sp.p: You ſeldom deal, I think, without one, Madam.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: My Pam box can beſt anſwer that hint, Madam; for this is the firſt guinea I have been able to put into it, this whole winter.—But you loſe, at preſent, Madam, and therefore have leave to ſpeak.—Pleaſe to mark the Loo, Madam—'tis juſt ſixty guineas.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: How much am 'I obliged to you, my excellent friend, for ſo generouſly ſaving me from the pain of offending the beſt of uncles!

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: And let me join my gratitude, Sir, for your having ſo kindly removed, I hope, the only obſtacle to my happineſs, by releaſing Sir William from his promiſe.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: I heartily wiſh he may be inclined to transfer his favour to you, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: My dear couſin, here's a place for you! The Monſters muſt come in with Mrs. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I'll wait upon you, in a moment.

sp.speaker: 2d Loo.
sp.p: The Monſters poſitively ſhall not come in, 'till 'tis a ſingle ſtake;—and then I ſhall never have a fluſh after, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: My dear Bromley, I have a thouſand things to ſay to you of the utmoſt importance. I wiſh you would not play, to-night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p:
Not play! you muſt excuſe me, indeed, Lady Mary! Beſides, we ſhall have time
enough to talk over thoſe ſame important matters, you know, at the Maſquerade.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I ſhall not go, to-night, and have ſomething ſo intereſting to tell you—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible ſhe ſhould ſuſpect any thing.—Your Ladyſhip knows I hate melancholy ſtories.— (to the Table) Is the Loo over?— (aſide) I can't help feeling a little aukward, when I ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: 3d Loo.
sp.p: Another fluſh, as I live! I don't believe we ſhall have a ſingle ſtake, theſe two hours.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Quadrille.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip's baſted—you trumpted the King of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: 2d Quadrille.
sp.p: What then, Madam? Here take the Diamond, I have my game without it.

sp.speaker: 3d Quadrille.
sp.p: No, Madam—a renounce is a Beaſt.

sp.speaker: 2d Quadrille.
sp.p: I won't ſubmit to it.—Judgment! Several. Your Ladyſhip's a Beaſt! a Beaſt!

sp.speaker: 2d Loo.
sp.p: What a racket they make, at this paltry play! Not above a crown a-fiſh, I dare ſwear!—The Loo is juſt two hundred and forty guineas!—Deal, Madam.
sp.stage: Enter Mr. WOODLEY, and joins LOUISA.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Not keep your promiſe, Bromley?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Why, no, indeed, Madam! I cannot poſſibly think of ruſticating myſelf with your Ladyſhip;—but if any of the ſummer camps ſhould happen to lie near you, I may give you a call, en paſſant, to ſee how love and a cottage agree with you.—Will you never let me in, Mrs. Henpeck?

sp.speaker: 3d Loo.
sp.p: Dear Madam, I wiſh you had been in my place, the whole evening, with all my heart! I have loſt near three hundred pounds in it.—Heighho!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p:
I had vainly flattered myſelf, it ſeems, that my company might have rendered the country
paſſable, at leaſt, to one who profeſſed herſelf my friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I always thought your Ladyſhip very romantic.— (aſide) I wiſh ſhe would not teaze me ſo!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: This ſhock is much ſeverer to me, than the firſt I felt, as friends were dearer to me than fortune.—But let me riſe above her worthleſſneſs, nor let her ſee how her unkindneſs wounds me.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Whiſt.
sp.p: Lurched at four! 'tis confounded hard!

sp.speaker: 2d Whiſt.
sp.p: I bet you three to one.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: — (to Mrs. Bromley) Will Mr. Bromley be here, to-night?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Certainly.—Sooner than you wiſh, I fancy.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Pray, Mrs. Bromley, did you hire thoſe ear-rings from my jeweller? I'm glad now, he did not alter them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I have never yet been under the neceſſity of hiring jewels, Madam, whatever other people may have been. But though the ſetting of theſe is not altered, Madam, the property is;—for they are mine, at preſent, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: You'll pardon me, Mrs. Bromley.—Mr. Woodley, pray are not thoſe my ear-rings?

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: They were, my dear.— (aſide) This is ungenerous of Bromley!—I will explain this matter another time, my dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Woodley, it requires but little explanation. Lady Mary is not ſo much a child as not to know, that, in this country, and in theſe times, property quickly changes hands, from thoſe who have ſquandered their own fortunes, and poſſibly that of others, to thoſe who have been more prudent, and leſs laviſh.

sp.speaker: 3d Loo.
sp.p: The Loo is over, Mrs. Bromley.—Bring the Monſters, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I thought it would never be a ſingle ſtake!

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Her unkindneſs would be inſupportable, did not the inſolence of it render her deſpicable.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Don't you think, Miſs Woodley, that Lady Mary looks uncommonly grave, this evening?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You will not be ſurpriſed at her ſeriouſneſs, when I tell you that ſhe has determined on quitting London immediately, and retiring with my brother into Dorſetſhire. I ſhall go with them, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: And I ſhall as certainly follow my leader. Sir William can have no objection to my being cantoned in the neighbourhood of Woodley Park, I preſume?

sp.speaker: 1ſt Whiſt.
sp.p: Four by honours, again! This is the fourth time you have dealt them, in the rubber. Sixteen out of twenty, are odds that Demoivre could not play againſt.—There's your money, there's your money, Sir!

sp.speaker: 2d Whiſt.
sp.p: No—double or quit with your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Whiſt.
sp.p: I know I am a bubble, but I hate to cut a loſer.—'Tis a bet, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: Two Pams, as I hope to be ſaved!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Fie, Madam, don't ſwear! 'tis vaſtly ill-bred.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: 'Tis much worſe breeding to cheat, Mrs. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: Mean creature! I ſcorn your words.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: You ſhould begin by ſcorning mean actions, Madam. But you ſhan't take up the Loo, I aſſure you—I have long ſuſpected you of ſuch tricks.

sp.speaker: 2d Loo.
sp.p: And ſo have I.—Heigh-ho!—ſhe has got a deal of my money.—Heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: 3d Loo.
sp.p: And of mine too, I aſſure you;—but her ſurpriſing luck is now clearly accounted for.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: I won't touch another card with ſuch vulgar, ſuſpicious wretches.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: We have renounced you firſt, Madam;—ſo if you pleaſe to riſe from the table, Madam, and I'll take care that you ſhall never ſit down to any other where-ever I am preſent, I aſſure you, Madam.

sp.speaker: 2d Loo.
sp.p: Put all the Monſters out, at once.—Heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.stage: (riſing in a paſſion, and addreſſing Lady Mary)
sp.p: I did not think your Ladyſhip would ſtand tamely by, and ſuffer me to be inſulted in your houſe; but 'tis the laſt time I ſhall ever come into it, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: I ſhall take care that you ſhan't break that promiſe, if you ſhou'd happen to forget it, Mrs. Bromley.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bromley.
sp.p: You ſpeak like an oracle, without conſciouſneſs, Madam; for this is the laſt night you will ever have any authority here, believe me: and ſo I leave your Ladyſhip to your future rural felicity.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Was there ever ſo ſudden and extraordinary a change in any human creature!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: 'Tis rather a diſcovery, than a metamorphoſe, my dear Lady Mary!—I have long ſeen through Mrs. Bromley's maſk—'twas only made of gauze.
sp.stage: Enter FORWARD, and ſpeaks to Mr. WOODLEY.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: There are ſome Gentlemen below, Sir, who, though not invited, inſiſt upon coming up.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Admit them, directly—all Gentlemen are welcome.

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: I ſhould have done ſo, Sir, but that theſe Gentlemen don't ſeem to be well enough dreſſed for my Lady's aſſembly—They are but Bailiffs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Diſtraction! my diſgrace is public, now!

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: At whoſe ſuit do they come here?

sp.speaker: Forward.
sp.p: I think they mentioned Mr. Bromley, Sir.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: Impoſſible! he is the very friend I thought of applying to, in my preſent difficulties.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Don't be too confident, Mr. Woodley. I know that fellow to be a conſummate knave.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: Don't let your ſpirits ſink, my dear Woodley.—We'll inquire into the matter, and accommodate it immediately.—I beg your Ladyſhip not to be alarmed—every thing ſhall be ſettled, directly. Try to ſupport your ſiſter's ſinking heart, my dear Louiſa.
sp.stage: [Louiſa ſeems to comfort Lady Mary, who is in Tears, and both go out together.]

sp.speaker: 2d Whiſt.
sp.p: Bailiffs, did the fellow ſay? Egad, I'll decamp in time.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Whiſt.
sp.p: You muſt not ſtir, 'till the rubber is out, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2d Whiſt.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip muſt excuſe me!—Such incidents are ſo common, to be ſure, in the preſent times, that they ceaſe to be ſcandalous; but that does not prevent my being affected by them. I ſhall remember that ſeven to four are the points of our game, and for debts of honour, my Lord, you'll always find me ſolvent.

sp.speaker: 3d Whiſt.
sp.p:
Theſe ſcenes are apt to affect me, too, Charles!—I never could ſtand them.—Peers are privileged from ſuch ſympathies; ſo let us countermarch
down the back-ſtairs, together, or we may be lurched, though we are ſeven.

sp.speaker: 2d Loo.
sp.p: I ſhall faint, if I ſee them!—I muſt go, Ladies.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: Let us have another round, Madam! We are all married women, you know.

sp.speaker: 2d Loo.
sp.p: My antipathy to theſe harpies was contracted while I was a widow, Madam.—'Tis your deal, Madam—Poor Lady Mary!—Heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: Ay, poor Lady Mary, I ſay too;—tho' to be ſure, one cannot have any great compaſſion for ſuch an extravagant woman.

sp.speaker: 3d Loo.
sp.p: Compaſſion! No, truly!—Such ſuppers after her routs! though I was never aſked to one of them. That cheat Bromley was one of her chief favourites, you know.

sp.speaker: 2d Loo.
sp.p: She is gone out of the room, as I live, without making the leaſt apology.—Did you ever hear of ſuch rudeneſs! I'll never viſit her again.—Heigh-ho!

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: Nor I.—'Tis time to break up, indeed, when the Lady of the houſe has retired!—I'll carry off this Pam, to triumph over that rude wretch, Bromley. I ſhall have the honour of ſeeing you all, to-morrow night.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: My coach was not ordered 'till twelve.—Will you carry me to Lady Freakiſh's rout? They never meet there, 'till eleven.

sp.speaker: 3d Loo.
sp.p: With pleaſure.—But I inſiſt upon telling the ſtory of the Woodleys.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Loo.
sp.p: And I of Mrs. Bromley.

sp.speaker: 2d Loo.
sp.p: Then I have nothing left to do, but to count my loſſes.—Heigh-ho!
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Sir WILLIAM'S Apartment.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Why didn't you ſay I was gone to bed? She'll break my reſt, for this night, at leaſt. She has heard of her misfortune, I fear.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: O Sir!—

sp.speaker: ſir William.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis all out, now.—Nay, my dear child, don't take on ſo—you'll break my heart, if you do.—'I was not my ſault, Louiſa.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: Don't talk or think of faults, now, Sir.—You know that before this diſgraceful event happened in the family—

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Don't you talk of it in ſuch a melancholy ſtrain, child;—'tis no diſgrace, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: 'Tis too public to be concealed, Sir. The Bailiffs are but this moment gone out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: What houſe? This houſe? Your brother's houſe? What! have they carried him to priſon? I thought it would come to this.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: No, Sir—Colonel Mountfort generouſly—

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: What had he to do with it? Why ſhould • olonel Mountfort, or any one elſe? Why didn't they ſend to me?—But what have I to do wi • h your brother, child? He ſhould have gone to pri • on.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: He would not long have languiſhed there, Sir believe me; a broken heart would ſoon have r • l • aſed him.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Pſha, pſha—with your broken heart—You play the fool with me!—My nephew periſh in a ga •• ! But he has brought it all on himſelf, you know, child.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I grant that his imprudence, Sir, has exceeded every thing, but your good-nature.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Confound my good-nature! it is for ever bringing me into ſcrapes—

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And bringing others out of them, my dear uncle.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Well, well, well—I want Belford, now, extremely!—Every thing falls out unlucky!—But what of Colonel Mountfort, child?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I was going to tell you, Sir, that he became ſecurity for my brother, on the inſtant.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: That's noble! for he did not know that I would diſcharge the debt.—Nay, for that matter, I don't know that I ſhall—I promiſe nothing—but I like this action of the Colonel.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I rejoice to hear it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Ay! then perhaps you like the Colonel? Be honeſt, ſpeak out.—I ſhould be glad to make you ſome amends for a loſs you don't yet know of;—but I can conceal it no longer.—Belſord has declared off!—but he is unworthy your reſentment. The Colonel's father was my friend, and a noble fellow he was!

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: And his ſon is every way worthy of ſuch a father!

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: (aſide) I rejoice to find her ſo eaſily reconciled.—Well, that matter is ſettled, for the preſent.—But are you certain that your brother and Lady Mary will hold their reſolution of retiring to Dorſetſhire?

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You know, Sir, it was their determined purpoſe, before this misfortune happened.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p:
That's ſomething in their favour, to be ſure, and I'm glad you told me of it.—One good act of choice, is worth all the virtues of neceſſity, in the world.—I ſhould be glad to make their minds eaſy, to-night—But they'd thank me, and talk to me, and diſcompoſe me, and I ſhould loſe my night's reſt—for I hate thanks.—I ſhould be glad to ſee Colonel
Mountfort:—his behaviour has ſhewn a reſpect to me, and the family.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: You will meet him now, at my brother's, Sir, where your preſence will make them all happy.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Well, child, I can deny you nothing.—I like to make people happy, when they'll aſſiſt me in doing ſo, themſelves; without which the beſt endeavours are but labour in vain.—But the country is the place!—You muſt ſettle in the country, Louiſa!—There is no ſafety for good folks in London, believe me, child.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I ſhould hope, Sir, that with prudence and virtue one might be ſafe any where.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: A fig for your prudence—ay, and for virtue too, againſt example! Example, child, is the ruin of us all. We naturally ſtrive to ape thoſe that are called our Betters, and ſo become worſe than we otherwiſe ſhould be.—But this is no time for moralizing. Do you ſtep in and tell your brother I am coming. I'll juſt wrap my cloak round me and follow you.
sp.stage: SCENE changes to Mr. WOODLEY's Dreſſing-room.
Mr. WOODLEY, Mr. BELFORD, and Colonel MOUNTFORT.

sp.speaker: Belford.
sp.p: Fear not, my gallant Colonel! Mr. Woodley ſhall have ample vengeance upon that ſcoundrel Bromley; for as he has evidently altered the date of the bond, we ſhall find a way to reward his ingenuity.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: I know not whether I am moſt aſtoniſhed at his villany, or at my own weakneſs in being duped by it.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: The uprightneſs of your own heart, my dear Woodley, is the beſt excuſe for your credulity.

sp.speaker: Louiſa.
sp.p: I come the happy meſſenger of joyful tidings! My dear good uncle—But he's here.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: I'm glad to meet you here, all together, for I have buſineſs with every one of you, jointly and ſeverally.—And firſt for you, Colonel, I am very much obliged to you, Sir, and I ſcorn to be obliged to any man, without making him ſome return for his kindneſs. I therefore make you a preſent I refuſed you, a few hours ago, for the ſake of old Sir Doubtful Deliberation there.—But do you take Louiſa, and for aught I know, you may make her as good a huſband as he would have done.

sp.speaker: Colonel.
sp.p: I ſhall uſe my beſt endeavours, Sir, to deſerve—

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: That's right—ſtick to that.—No thanks, but deſerve as much as ever you can.—And as for you, Mr. Belford, though I am confoundedly angry with you, I muſt get you to ſettle this young man's affairs; his debts of honour, his poſt obits, &c.; though perhaps it may be only affording him an opportunity for deranging them again.—That's the modern phraſe, I think, for being over-head-and-ears in debt.

sp.speaker: Woodley.
sp.p: The ſufferings my follies have brought upon me, Sir, and the remembrance of your generoſity, will remain too ſtrongly impreſſed on my mind, to admit of my relapſing into my former errors; as that would be adding ingratitude to extravagance, and vice to folly.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p:
Well, well, I hope ſo.—Kindneſs ſhould be the ſtrongeſt tie to a generous mind, and I ſuſpect you not of any baſeneſs in your nature;—though, to be ſure, you have ſhewn a plentiful lack of wiſdom in your conduct. But misfortunes
make Solomons of us all!—And now, Madam, (to Lady Mary) to ſhew you that the merit of your voluntary retirement into the country, is not loſt upon me, I make you a preſent of this houſe, for your winter reſidence.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Your kindneſs, Sir,—

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: Stop there—I won't be thanked—I wiſh to do as I would be done by; and as I ſhould not like to be confined in the fineſt place in the world, not even Woodley Park, I would not impoſe ſuch a reſtraint on one who I doubt not will hereafter merit my indulgence.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: Gratitude overwhelms me, Sir!—I cannot ſpeak my ſenſe of your goodneſs as it deſerves.

sp.speaker: Sir William.
sp.p: So much the better!—There are nobler ways of ſhewing one's ſentiments.

sp.speaker: L. Mary.
sp.p: They ſhall be demonſtrated in my future conduct, Sir; for the virtue that ariſes from the conviction of paſt errors, muſt be at once ſincere, and permanent.
